paragraph.content: not more than one private copy of the original copy is made and stored in each device lawfully owned by the owner; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the owner retains the ownership of both the original copy and the private copy.

subsection.leadIn: A private copy that, but for subsection (1), would be an infringing copy is to be treated as an infringing copy if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: it is used otherwise than for the purpose mentioned in subsection (1)(b); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the condition mentioned in subsection (1)(c) or (d) is broken.

section.name: s77
section.heading: Incidental recording for purposes of broadcast or cable programme

subsection.leadIn: This section applies where by virtue of a licence or assignment of copyright a person is authorized to broadcast or include in a cable programme service—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a literary, dramatic or musical work, or an adaptation of such a work;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an artistic work; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a sound recording or film.

subsection.leadIn: He is by virtue of this section to be treated as licensed by the owner of the copyright in the work to do or authorize any of the following for the purposes of the broadcast or cable programme—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: in the case of an artistic work, to take a photograph or make a film of the work;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: in the case of a sound recording or film, to make a copy of it.

subsection.leadIn: That licence is subject to the condition that the sound recording, film, photograph or copy in question—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: must not be used for any other purposes;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: must be destroyed within 3 months of being first used for broadcasting the work or, as the case may be, including it in a cable programme service.

subsection.leadIn: A sound recording, film, photograph or copy made in accordance with this section is treated as an infringing copy—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for the purposes of any use in breach of the condition mentioned in subsection (3)(a); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for all purposes after that condition or the condition mentioned in subsection (3)(b) is broken.

section.name: s78
section.heading: Recording for purposes of supervision and control of broadcasts and cable programmes

subsection.content: Copyright is not infringed by the making or use by Radio Television Hong Kong, for the purposes of maintaining supervision and control over programmes broadcast by them, of recordings of those programmes.

subsection.leadIn: Copyright is not infringed by the making or use of recordings—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: by the Communications Authority for the performance of its functions mentioned in section 9 of the Broadcasting (Miscellaneous Provisions) Ordinance (Cap. 391); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: pursuant to the instructions of the Communications Authority in the performance of those functions. (Amended 17 of 2011 s. 28)

section.name: s79
section.heading: Recording for purposes of time-shifting
section.content: The making for private and domestic use of a recording of a broadcast or cable programme solely for the purpose of enabling it to be viewed or listened to at a more convenient time does not infringe any copyright in the broadcast or cable programme or in any work included in it.

section.name: s80
section.heading: Photographs of television broadcasts or cable programmes
section.content: The making for private and domestic use of a photograph of the whole or any part of an image forming part of a television broadcast or cable programme, or a copy of such a photograph, does not infringe any copyright in the broadcast or cable programme or in any film included in it.

section.name: s81
section.heading: Free public showing or playing of broadcast or cable programme

subsection.leadIn: The showing or playing in public of a broadcast or cable programme (other than an encrypted broadcast or cable programme) to an audience who have not paid for admission to the place where the broadcast or programme is to be seen or heard does not infringe any copyright in—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the broadcast or cable programme; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any sound recording or film included in it.

subsection.leadIn: The audience are treated as having paid for admission to a place—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if they have paid for admission to a place of which that place forms part; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: if goods or services are supplied at that place (or a place of which it forms part)—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: at prices which are substantially attributable to the facilities afforded for seeing or hearing the broadcast or programme; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: at prices exceeding those usually charged there and which are partly attributable to those facilities.

subsection.leadIn: The following are not regarded as having paid for admission to a place—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: persons admitted as residents or inmates of the place which is operated by a charitable organization and the facilities therein are not provided for profit;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: persons admitted as members of a club or society whose main objects are charitable or are otherwise concerned with the advancement of religion, education or social welfare and where the payment is only for membership of the club or society and the provision of facilities for seeing or hearing broadcasts or programmes is only incidental to the main purposes of the club or society.

subsection.content: Where the making of the broadcast or inclusion of the programme in a cable programme service was an infringement of the copyright in a sound recording or film, the fact that it was heard or seen in public by the reception of the broadcast or programme is to be taken into account in assessing the damages for that infringement.

section.name: s81A
section.heading: Playing of sound broadcasts inside vehicles

subsection.content: The playing of a sound broadcast inside a vehicle primarily for the purpose of affording the driver of the vehicle access to public information (including but not limited to news reports, weather forecasts and information relating to road traffic) does not infringe the copyright in the sound broadcast, any sound recording included in it or any literary, dramatic or musical work included in it.

subsection.def: In subsection (1), vehicle (車輛) means any vehicle constructed or adapted for use on roads.

section.name: s82
section.heading: Reception and re-transmission of broadcast in cable programme service

subsection.leadIn: The copyright in a television broadcast or a sound broadcast is not infringed by any person who, by the reception and immediate re-transmission of the broadcast without any alteration, includes a programme in a service provided—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: by a communal aerial broadcast distribution system within the scope of section 8(4)(e) of the Telecommunications Ordinance (Cap. 106);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: by an interconnection between a communal aerial broadcast distribution system within the scope of section 8(4)(e) of the Telecommunications Ordinance (Cap. 106) and a subscription television network licensed, or deemed to be licensed, under the Telecommunications Ordinance (Cap. 106), where the re-transmission is for the reception of the users of the communal aerial broadcast distribution system; or (Amended 48 of 2000 s. 44)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: by a system licensed under a broadcast relay station licence issued under the Telecommunications Ordinance (Cap. 106). (Amended 36 of 2000 s. 28; 17 of 2011 s. 28)

subsection.leadIn: The copyright in a television broadcast which is not encrypted or in a sound broadcast which is not encrypted is not infringed by any person who, by the reception and immediate re-transmission of the broadcast without any alteration, includes a programme in a service provided—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: by a system licensed under a satellite master antenna television licence issued under the Telecommunications Ordinance (Cap. 106); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: by an interconnection between a system licensed under a satellite master antenna television licence issued under the Telecommunications Ordinance (Cap. 106) and a subscription television network licensed, or deemed to be licensed, under the Telecommunications Ordinance (Cap. 106) and where the re-transmission is for the reception of the users of the satellite master antenna television system, (Amended 48 of 2000 s. 44)

subsection.continued: until the expiration of 6 months beginning on the day of publication of the notice in accordance with subsection (5). (Amended 36 of 2000 s. 28; 17 of 2011 s. 28)

subsection.content: Where a television broadcast or sound broadcast is made or uplinked from a place in Hong Kong or elsewhere, and the broadcast is a lawful broadcast, then any person who, by the reception and immediate re-transmission of the broadcast without any alteration, includes a programme in a service provided by a system or an interconnection specified in subsection (1) or (2), being a programme comprising a literary, dramatic or musical work, or an adaptation of such a work, or an artistic work, or a sound recording or film, shall be in a like position, in any proceedings for infringement of the copyright (if any) in the work, recording or film, as if he had been the holder of a licence granted by the owner of that copyright to include the work, adaptation, recording or film in any programme so included in that service.

Where a television broadcast or a sound broadcast is not encrypted, the person who, by the reception and immediate re-transmission of the broadcast without any alteration, includes a programme in a service provided by a system or interconnection specified in subsection (2) is deemed to have been granted an implied licence by the maker of the broadcast to receive and re-transmit the broadcast using the system which is only revocable by notice given in accordance with subsection (5).

subsection.leadIn: The maker of a broadcast in respect of which a licence is deemed to have been granted under subsection (4) may revoke the licence by publishing a notice of revocation in—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: 1 Chinese language newspaper circulating in Hong Kong; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: 1 English language newspaper circulating in Hong Kong.

section.name: s83
section.heading: Provision of sub-titled copies of broadcast or cable programme

subsection.content: A body designated under subsection (3) may, for the purpose of providing people who are deaf or hard of hearing, or physically or mentally handicapped in other ways, with copies which are sub-titled or otherwise modified for their special needs, make copies of television broadcasts or cable programmes, communicate the broadcasts or cable programmes to the public or issue copies of the broadcasts or cable programmes to the public, without infringing any copyright in the broadcasts or cable programmes or works included in them. (Amended 16 of 2022 s. 55)

This section does not apply if, or to the extent that, licences under licensing schemes are available authorizing the act in question and the person so acting knew or ought to have been aware of that fact.

The Secretary for Commerce and Economic Development may, by notice in the Gazette, designate bodies for the purposes of this section, and the Secretary shall not designate a body unless he is satisfied that it is not established or conducted for profit. (Amended L.N. 173 of 2000; L.N. 106 of 2002; L.N. 130 of 2007)

section.name: s84
section.heading: Recording for archival purposes

subsection.content: A recording of a broadcast or cable programme of a class designated under subsection (2), or a copy of such a recording, may be made for the purpose of being placed in an archive maintained by a body designated under subsection (2) without thereby infringing any copyright in the broadcast or cable programme or in any work included in it.

The Secretary for Commerce and Economic Development may, by notice in the Gazette, designate any class of broadcast or of cable programme and any body for the purposes of this section, and the Secretary shall not designate a body unless he is satisfied that it is not established or conducted for profit. (Amended L.N. 173 of 2000; L.N. 106 of 2002; L.N. 130 of 2007)

section.name: s85
section.heading: Adaptations
section.content: An act which by virtue of this Division may be done without infringing copyright in a literary, dramatic or musical work does not, where that work is an adaptation, infringe any copyright in the work from which the adaptation was made.

section.name: s86
section.heading: Corresponding design
section.content: In sections 87 and 88, a corresponding design (相應外觀設計), in relation to an artistic work, means a design within the meaning of the Registered Designs Ordinance (Cap. 522) which if applied to an article would produce something which would be treated for the purposes of this Part as a copy of the artistic work.

section.name: s87
section.heading: Effect of exploitation of design derived from artistic work

subsection.leadIn: This section applies where an artistic work has been exploited, by or with the licence of the copyright owner, by—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: making by an industrial process articles falling to be treated for the purposes of this Part as copies of the work; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: marketing such articles, in Hong Kong or elsewhere.

subsection.content: After the end of the period of 25 years from the end of the calendar year in which such articles incorporating a registered corresponding design are first marketed, the work may be copied by making articles of any description, or doing anything for the purpose of making articles of any description, and anything may be done in relation to articles so made, without infringing copyright in the work.

After the end of the period of 15 years from the end of the calendar year in which such articles incorporating an unregistered corresponding design are first marketed, the work may be copied by making articles of any description, or doing anything for the purpose of making articles of any description, and anything may be done in relation to articles so made, without infringing copyright in the work.
Where only part of an artistic work is exploited as mentioned in subsection (1), subsection (2) or (3) applies only in relation to that part.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.def: registered corresponding design (經註冊的相應外觀設計) means a corresponding design which has been registered under the Registered Designs Ordinance (Cap. 522);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.def: unregistered corresponding design (未經註冊的相應外觀設計) means a corresponding design which has not been registered under the Registered Designs Ordinance (Cap. 522), and includes a corresponding design which is not registrable under that Ordinance;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: references to articles do not include films;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: references to the marketing of an article are to its being sold or let for hire or offered or exposed for sale or hire.

section.name: s88
section.heading: Things done in reliance on registration of design
section.leadIn: The copyright in an artistic work is not infringed by anything done—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in pursuance of an assignment or licence made or granted by a person registered under the Registered Designs Ordinance (Cap. 522) as the registered owner of a corresponding design; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in good faith in reliance on the registration and without notice of any proceedings for the cancellation of the registration or for rectifying the relevant entry in the register of designs,

section.continued: and this is so notwithstanding that the person registered as the registered owner was not the owner of the design for the purposes of that Ordinance.

division.name: D3A
division.heading: Limitations on Liability of Service Providers relating to Online Materials

section.name: s88A
section.heading: Definitions
section.leadIn: In this Division—
section.def: code of practice (《實務守則》) means the code of practice published by the Secretary for Commerce and Economic Development under section 88J;
counter notice (異議通知) means a notice given to a service provider under section 88E(1) in relation to an alleged copyright infringement;
notice of alleged infringement (指稱侵權通知) means a notice given to a service provider under section 88C(1) in relation to an alleged copyright infringement;
online service (聯線服務) has the meaning given by section 65A(2) but does not include any service provided through an intranet;
personal data (個人資料) has the meaning given by section 2(1) of the Personal Data (Privacy) Ordinance (Cap. 486);
service provider (服務提供者) has the meaning given by section 65A(2);

standard technical measure (標準技術措施) means any technical measure generally accepted by the industry that—(a)is used to identify or protect copyright works;(b)has been developed through an open, voluntary process by a broad consensus of copyright owners and service providers;(c)is available to any person on reasonable and non-discriminatory terms; and(d)does not impose substantial costs on service providers or substantial burdens on the systems or networks controlled or operated by or for service providers.

section.name: s88B
section.heading: Limitations on liability of service providers

subsection.content: If the conditions specified in subsection (2) are complied with, a service provider is not liable for damages or any other pecuniary remedy for infringement of the copyright in a work that occurs on the provider’s service platform merely because the provider provides, or operates facilities for, online services.

subsection.leadIn: The conditions are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: that the service provider has taken reasonable steps to limit or stop the infringement as soon as practicable after the provider—

subparagraph.content: received a notice of alleged infringement in relation to the infringement;
became aware that the infringement has occurred; or
became aware of the facts or circumstances that would lead inevitably to the conclusion that the infringement had occurred;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: that the service provider has not received and is not receiving any financial benefit directly attributable to the infringement;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: that the service provider accommodates and does not interfere with the standard technical measures that are used by copyright owners to identify or protect their copyright works; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: that the service provider designates an agent to receive notices of alleged infringements, by supplying through the provider’s service, including on the provider’s website at a location accessible to the public, the agent’s name and contact details.

subsection.content: For the purposes of subsection (2)(a), a service provider is to be treated as having taken reasonable steps to limit or stop the infringement in question if the provider complies with all the provisions in the code of practice respecting the course of action that a service provider may adopt in limiting or stopping an alleged infringement.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (2)(b)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: in determining whether a service provider has received or is receiving a financial benefit directly attributable to the infringement in question, the court may take into account all the circumstances of the case and, in particular—

subparagraph.content: whether the fee for the online service provided by the provider is for, and the value of the online service provided by the provider lies in, providing access to infringing material; and

whether the financial benefit received by the provider for providing the online service to which the infringement relates is greater than the benefit that would usually result from charging for the online service in accordance with accepted industry practices; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: without limiting paragraph (a), financial benefits directly attributable to the infringement do not include one-off set up fees and flat periodic payments that are charged by the service provider in respect of all users on a non-discriminatory basis.

subsection.leadIn: To avoid doubt—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: nothing in this Division requires a service provider to—

subparagraph.content: monitor the provider’s service or actively seek facts that indicate infringing activity, except to the extent consistent with a standard technical measure complying with subsection (2)(c); or
gain access to, remove, or disable access to material in cases where such actions are prohibited by law,

paragraph.continued: in order to qualify for the limitations on liability established by this section; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the failure of a service provider to qualify for the limitations on liability established by this section has no adverse bearing on the consideration of any defence that may be available to the provider in proceedings for infringement of copyright.

subsection.content: This section does not apply to proceedings for infringement of copyright commenced before the day on which this section comes into operation*.

section.name: s88C
section.heading: Notice of alleged infringement

subsection.content: If it is alleged that an infringement of the copyright in a work has occurred or is occurring on a service provider’s service platform, a notice in respect of the alleged infringement may be given to the provider under this section.

subsection.leadIn: The notice of alleged infringement—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: must be in writing;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: (if the service provider specifies the form of the notice under subsection (5)) must be in the form specified by the provider;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: must be signed or otherwise authenticated by the owner of the allegedly infringed copyright or that owner’s authorized representative; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: must be provided to the designated agent of the service provider by the means specified by the provider under subsection (6).

subsection.leadIn: In addition, the notice of alleged infringement—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: must substantially identify the copyright work that is alleged to have been infringed;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: must identify—

subparagraph.content: the activity, or the link or reference to the activity, that is alleged to be infringing;

paragraph.name: d
e
f
paragraph.content: must contain a statement to the effect that the complainant believes in good faith that use of the material, or conduct of the activity, in the manner complained of is not authorized by law, and has not been authorized by the copyright owner or the authorized representative of the copyright owner;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.leadIn: must contain a statement to the effect that the complainant requests the service provider to—

subparagraph.content: if applicable, remove the material to which the alleged infringement relates, or disable access to the material or activity to which the alleged infringement relates; and

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.leadIn: must contain a declaration to the effect that—

subparagraph.content: the information contained in the notice is true and accurate to the best of the complainant’s knowledge and belief;
the complainant is the copyright owner or is authorized to act on behalf of the copyright owner; and
the complainant understands that the complainant may incur criminal or civil liability for making false statements in the notice.

subsection.leadIn: If a notice of alleged infringement given to a service provider does not comply with subsection (2) or (3)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the notice is of no effect for the purposes of section 88B(2)(a)(i); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in determining whether the provider was aware of any of the matters mentioned in section 88B(2)(a)(ii) or (iii), no account is to be taken of the notice.

subsection.content: For the purposes of subsection (2)(b), a service provider may specify the form of a notice of alleged infringement in so far as it is not inconsistent with the provisions in subsection (3).

For the purposes of subsection (2)(d), a service provider must specify, through the provider’s service (which may include on the provider’s website), the means (which may include electronic means) by which a notice of alleged infringement is to be provided to the designated agent of the provider.

subsection.leadIn: On receiving a notice of alleged infringement from a complainant, a service provider may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: send a copy of the notice to the provider’s subscriber whose account for online services has been used or involved in the alleged infringement;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: notify the subscriber that the subscriber may contact the complainant directly;

paragraph.name: c
d
paragraph.content: (if the provider removes the material to which the alleged infringement relates, or disables access to the material or activity to which the alleged infringement relates) notify the subscriber of the removal or disabling.

section.name: s88D
section.heading: Notice given by service provider
section.leadIn: If a service provider becomes aware that an infringement of the copyright in a work has occurred on the provider’s service platform or becomes aware of the facts or circumstances that would lead inevitably to the conclusion that the infringement has occurred, the provider may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: remove the material to which the infringement relates, or disable access to the material or activity to which the infringement relates; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: by written notice given to the provider’s subscriber whose account for online services has been used or involved in the infringement, notify the subscriber of the removal or disabling.

section.name: s88E
section.heading: Counter notice

subsection.leadIn: Within a reasonable time after receiving a copy of a notice of alleged infringement sent by the service provider under section 88C(7)(a) in respect of the matter mentioned in section 88C(7)(d) or a notice given by the provider under section 88D(b), the provider’s subscriber may give a counter notice to the provider—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: disputing or denying the infringement alleged by the complainant or provider; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: requesting the provider to take reasonable steps to reinstate the material, or cease disabling access to the material or activity, within a reasonable time after receiving the counter notice.

subsection.leadIn: The counter notice—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: must be in writing;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: (if the service provider specifies the form of the counter notice under subsection (5)) must be in the form specified by the provider;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: must be signed or otherwise authenticated by the subscriber; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: must be provided to the designated agent of the service provider by the means specified by the provider under subsection (6).

subsection.leadIn: In addition, the counter notice—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.leadIn: must identify—

subparagraph.content: the material that has been removed or to which access has been disabled, and the location at which the material appeared before it was removed or access to it was disabled; or
the activity to which access has been disabled, and the location at which the activity appeared before access to it was disabled;

paragraph.name: c
d
paragraph.content: must contain the grounds for the subscriber’s belief mentioned in paragraph (c);

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: (if the subscriber is an individual) must state whether the subscriber opts for or against the service provider’s disclosure of the subscriber’s personal data contained in the counter notice to the complainant; and

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.leadIn: must contain a declaration to the effect that—

subparagraph.content: the information contained in the counter notice is true and accurate to the best of the subscriber’s knowledge and belief; and
the subscriber understands that the subscriber may incur criminal or civil liability for making false statements in the counter notice.

subsection.content: A counter notice that does not comply with subsection (2) or (3) is of no effect for the purposes of subsection (1)(b).
For the purposes of subsection (2)(b), a service provider may specify the form of a counter notice in so far as it is not inconsistent with the provisions in subsection (3).

For the purposes of subsection (2)(d), a service provider must specify, through the provider’s service (which may include on the provider’s website), the means (which may include electronic means) by which a counter notice is to be provided to the designated agent of the provider.

section.name: s88F
section.heading: Offence for making false statements

subsection.leadIn: A person commits an offence if the person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: makes any statement in a notice of alleged infringement or counter notice that the person knows to be false in a material respect; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: recklessly makes any statement in a notice of alleged infringement or counter notice that is false in a material respect.

subsection.content: A person who commits an offence under subsection (1) is liable on conviction to a fine at level 2 and to imprisonment for 2 years.

section.name: s88G
section.heading: Civil liability for making false statements

subsection.content: A person who makes any statement in a notice of alleged infringement or counter notice that the person knows to be false, or does not believe to be true, in a material respect, is liable in damages to any person who suffers loss or damage as a result of the making of the statement.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: loss or damage (損失或損害), in relation to a statement, means loss or damage that is actual and reasonably foreseeable as likely to result from the making of the statement.

section.name: s88H
section.heading: Exemption of service providers from liability for removal of material etc.

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (2), if a service provider has, in good faith, removed any material, or disabled access to any material or activity, pursuant to a notice of alleged infringement, the provider is not liable to any person for any claim made in respect of the removal or disabling, whether or not the relevant material or activity is ultimately determined to be infringing.

subsection.leadIn: Subsection (1) does not apply to material residing at the direction of a subscriber of the service provider on the provider’s service platform and that is removed, or to material or activity residing at the direction of a subscriber of the provider on the provider’s service platform and to which access is disabled, unless—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: the provider takes reasonable steps to send a copy of the notice of alleged infringement to the subscriber; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: if the subscriber gives a counter notice to the provider—

subparagraph.content: the provider promptly sends a copy of the counter notice to the complainant;
(if the subscriber is an individual) the provider acts in accordance with the subscriber’s option stated in the counter notice under section 88E(3)(e); and

subject to subsection (7), the provider takes reasonable steps to reinstate the material, or cease disabling access to the material or activity, within a reasonable time after receiving the counter notice.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (4), if a service provider has, in good faith, removed any material, or disabled access to any material or activity, after the provider—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: became aware that the material or activity relates to an infringement of copyright; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: became aware of the facts or circumstances that would lead inevitably to the conclusion that the infringement had occurred,

subsection.continued: the provider is not liable to any person for any claim made in respect of the removal or disabling, whether or not the relevant material or activity is ultimately determined to be infringing.

subsection.leadIn: Subsection (3) does not apply to material residing at the direction of a subscriber of the service provider on the provider’s service platform and that is removed, or to material or activity residing at the direction of a subscriber of the provider on the provider’s service platform and to which access is disabled, unless—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.leadIn: the provider takes reasonable steps to provide the subscriber with—

subparagraph.content: information reasonably sufficient to enable the subscriber to identify the material or activity; and
the provider’s reasons for the removal or disabling; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: subject to subsection (7), if the subscriber gives a counter notice to the provider, the provider takes reasonable steps to reinstate the material, or cease disabling access to the material or activity, within a reasonable time after receiving the counter notice.

subsection.content: Subject to subsections (6) and (7), if a service provider has, in good faith, reinstated any material, or ceased disabling access to any material or activity, pursuant to a counter notice, the provider is not liable to any person for any claim made in respect of the reinstatement or cessation, whether or not the relevant material or activity is ultimately determined to be infringing.

subsection.leadIn: Subsection (5) does not apply in a case where the material was removed, or access to the material or activity was disabled, pursuant to a notice of alleged infringement, unless—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the service provider promptly sends a copy of the counter notice to the complainant; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: (if the subscriber is an individual) the provider acts in accordance with the subscriber’s option stated in the counter notice under section 88E(3)(e).

subsection.leadIn: Subsections (2)(c)(iii), (4)(c) and (5) do not apply if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: proceedings have been commenced in Hong Kong seeking a court order in connection with any infringing activity that relates to the material or activity mentioned in those subsections; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the designated agent of the service provider has been notified in writing, by the person who brings the proceedings, of the proceedings—

subparagraph.content: in the case of subsection (2)(c)(iii) or (5), within a reasonable time after the provider sent a copy of the counter notice to the complainant; or
in the case of subsection (4)(c), within a reasonable time after the provider received the counter notice.

section.name: s88I
section.heading: Evidence of compliance with conditions
section.leadIn: In an action relating to the liability of a service provider, if the provider adduces evidence tending to show that the provider has complied with—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a condition described in section 88B(2); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a condition specified in the code of practice,

section.continued: the court must presume, in the absence of evidence to the contrary, that the provider has complied with that condition.

section.name: s88J
section.heading: Code of practice

subsection.content: The Secretary for Commerce and Economic Development may publish in the Gazette a code of practice for providing practical guidance to service providers in respect of this Division.

subsection.leadIn: Without limiting subsection (1), the Secretary may in the code of practice specify—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: the procedures for giving a notice of alleged infringement or counter notice, including—

subparagraph.content: the forms of, and the information to be contained in, the notice;
the manner of sending the notice; and
the manner of verification of statements in the notice; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the course of action that a service provider may adopt on receiving a notice of alleged infringement or counter notice.

subsection.leadIn: In any proceedings, if the court is satisfied that a provision of the code of practice is relevant to determining a matter that is in issue in the proceedings—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the code of practice is admissible in evidence in the proceedings; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: proof that a person contravened or did not contravene the provision may be relied on as tending to establish or negate that matter.

subsection.content: The Secretary may amend the code of practice in a manner consistent with the Secretary’s power to publish the code, and a reference to the code in this Division is to be construed as including a reference to the code as so amended.
Neither the code of practice, nor any amendment made to it, is subsidiary legislation.

division.name: D4
division.heading: Moral Rights
division.crossHeading: Right to be identified as author or director

section.name: s89
section.heading: Right to be identified as author or director

subsection.content: The author of a copyright literary, dramatic, musical or artistic work, and the director of a copyright film, has the right to be identified as the author or director of the work in the circumstances mentioned in this section; but the right is not infringed unless it has been asserted in accordance with section 90.

subsection.leadIn: The author of a literary work (other than words intended to be sung or spoken with music) or a dramatic work has the right to be identified whenever—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the work is published commercially, performed in public or communicated to the public; or

paragraph.name: b

subsection.continued: and that right includes the right to be identified whenever any of those events occur in relation to an adaptation of the work as the author of the work from which the adaptation was made.

subsection.leadIn: The author of a musical work, or a literary work consisting of words intended to be sung or spoken with music, has the right to be identified whenever—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: a sound recording of the work is made available to the public, or copies of such a sound recording are issued to the public; or (Replaced 16 of 2022 s. 57)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a film of which the sound-track includes the work is shown in public or made available to the public, or copies of such a film are issued to the public, (Replaced 16 of 2022 s. 57)

subsection.continued: and that right includes the right to be identified whenever any of those events occur in relation to an adaptation of the work as the author of the work from which the adaptation was made.

subsection.leadIn: The author of an artistic work has the right to be identified whenever—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: a film including a visual image of the work is shown in public or made available to the public, or copies of such a film are issued to the public; or (Replaced 16 of 2022 s. 57)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: in the case of a work of architecture in the form of a building or a model for a building, a sculpture or a work of artistic craftsmanship, a graphic work representing it or a photograph of it is made available to the public, or copies of such a graphic work or photograph are issued to the public.

subsection.content: The author of a work of architecture in the form of a building also has the right to be identified on the building as constructed or, where more than one building is constructed to the design, on the first to be constructed.
The director of a film has the right to be identified whenever the film is shown in public or communicated to the public, or copies of the film are issued to the public.

subsection.leadIn: The right of the author or director under this section is—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the case of commercial publication or the issue to the public of copies of a film or sound recording, to be identified in or on each copy or, if that is not appropriate, in some other manner likely to bring his identity to the notice of a person acquiring a copy;

paragraph.name: ab
paragraph.content: in the case of making a film or sound recording available to the public, to be identified in or on the film or sound recording or, if that is not appropriate, in some other manner likely to bring the author’s or director’s identity to the notice of a person acquiring the film or sound recording; (Added 16 of 2022 s. 57)

paragraph.name: b
c
paragraph.content: in any other case, to be identified in a manner likely to bring his identity to the notice of a person seeing or hearing the performance, exhibition, showing or communication in question,

subsection.continued: and the identification must in each case be clear and reasonably prominent.

subsection.content: If the author or director in asserting his right to be identified specifies a pseudonym, initials or some other particular form of identification, that form must be used; otherwise any reasonable form of identification may be used.
This section has effect subject to section 91.

section.name: s90
section.heading: Requirement that right be asserted

subsection.content: A person does not infringe the right conferred by section 89 (right to be identified as author or director) by doing any of the acts mentioned in that section unless the right has been asserted in accordance with the following provisions so as to bind him in relation to that act.

subsection.leadIn: The right may be asserted generally, or in relation to any specified act or description of acts—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on an assignment of copyright in the work, by including in the instrument effecting the assignment a statement that the author or director asserts in relation to that work his right to be identified; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: by instrument in writing signed by the author or director.

subsection.leadIn: The right may also be asserted in relation to the public exhibition of an artistic work—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: by securing that when the author or other first owner of copyright parts with possession of the original, or of a copy made by him or under his direction or control, the author is identified on the original or copy, or on a frame, mount or other thing to which it is attached; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: by including in a licence by which the author or other first owner of copyright authorizes the making of copies of the work a written statement signed by or on behalf of the person granting the licence that the author asserts his right to be identified in the event of the public exhibition of a copy made in pursuance of the licence.

subsection.leadIn: The persons bound by an assertion of the right under subsection (2) or (3) are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the case of an assertion under subsection (2)(a), the assignee and anyone claiming through him, whether or not he has notice of the assertion;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the case of an assertion under subsection (2)(b), anyone to whose notice the assertion is brought;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: in the case of an assertion under subsection (3)(a), anyone into whose hands that original or copy comes, whether or not the identification is still present or visible;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: in the case of an assertion under subsection (3)(b), the licensee and anyone into whose hands a copy made in pursuance of the licence comes, whether or not he has notice of the assertion.

subsection.content: In an action for infringement of the right the court shall, in considering remedies, take into account any delay in asserting the right.

section.name: s91
section.heading: Exceptions to right

subsection.content: The right conferred by section 89 (right to be identified as author or director) is subject to the following exceptions.

subsection.leadIn: The right does not apply in relation to the following descriptions of work—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a computer program;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the design of a typeface;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: any computer-generated work.

subsection.content: The right does not apply to anything done by or with the authority of the copyright owner where copyright in the work originally vested in the author’s employer by virtue of section 14(1) (employee works).

subsection.leadIn: The right is not infringed by an act which by virtue of any of the following provisions would not infringe copyright in the work—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: section 39 (criticism, review, quotation, and reporting and commenting on current events); (Replaced 16 of 2022 s. 58)

paragraph.name: ab
paragraph.content: section 39A (parody, satire, caricature and pastiche); (Added 16 of 2022 s. 58)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: section 40 (incidental inclusion of work in an artistic work, sound recording, film, broadcast or cable programme);

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: section 41(3) (examination questions);

paragraph.name: ca
paragraph.content: section 54B (Legislative Council); (Added 15 of 2007 s. 24)

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: section 54 (judicial proceedings); (Amended 15 of 2007 s. 24)

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: section 55(1) or (2) (statutory inquiries);

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: section 66 or 75 (acts permitted on assumptions as to expiry of copyright, etc.).

subsection.content: The right does not apply in relation to any work made for the purpose of reporting current events.

subsection.leadIn: The right does not apply in relation to the publication in—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a newspaper, magazine or similar periodical; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an encyclopaedia, dictionary, yearbook or other collective work of reference,

subsection.continued: of a literary, dramatic, musical or artistic work made for the purposes of such publication or made available with the consent of the author for the purposes of such publication.

subsection.leadIn: The right does not apply in relation to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a work in which Government copyright or Legislative Council copyright subsists; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a work in which copyright originally vested in an international organization by virtue of section 188,

subsection.continued: unless the author or director has previously been identified as such in or on published copies of the work.

division.crossHeading: Right to object to derogatory treatment of work

section.name: s92
section.heading: Right to object to derogatory treatment of work

subsection.content: The author of a copyright literary, dramatic, musical or artistic work, and the director of a copyright film, has the right in the circumstances mentioned in this section not to have his work subjected to derogatory treatment.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of this section—

def.name: Treatment
def.leadIn: treatment (處理) of a work means any addition to, deletion from or alteration to or adaptation of the work, other than—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: a translation of a literary or dramatic work; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: an arrangement or transcription of a musical work involving no more than a change of key or register; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the treatment of a work is derogatory if it amounts to distortion or mutilation of the work or is otherwise prejudicial to the honour or reputation of the author or director,

subsection.continued: and in the following provisions of this section references to a derogatory treatment of a work are construed accordingly.

subsection.leadIn: In the case of a literary, dramatic or musical work the right is infringed by a person who—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: publishes commercially, performs in public or communicates to the public a derogatory treatment of the work; or (Amended 16 of 2022 s. 59)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: makes available to the public a film or sound recording of, or including, a derogatory treatment of the work, or issues copies of such a film or sound recording to the public. (Replaced 16 of 2022 s. 59)

subsection.leadIn: In the case of an artistic work the right is infringed by a person who—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: publishes commercially or exhibits in public a derogatory treatment of the work, or communicates to the public a visual image of a derogatory treatment of the work;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: shows in public a film including a visual image of a derogatory treatment of the work, makes such a film available to the public or issues copies of such a film to the public; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: in the case of—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: a work of architecture in the form of a model for a building;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: a sculpture; or

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: a work of artistic craftsmanship,

paragraph.continued: makes available to the public a graphic work representing, or a photograph of, a derogatory treatment of the work, or issues copies of such a graphic work or photograph to the public. (Amended 16 of 2022 s. 59)

subsection.content: Subsection (4) does not apply to a work of architecture in the form of a building; but where the author of such a work is identified on the building and it is the subject of derogatory treatment he has the right to require the identification to be removed.

subsection.leadIn: In the case of a film, the right is infringed by a person who—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: shows in public or communicates to the public a derogatory treatment of the film; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: issues to the public copies of a derogatory treatment of the film. (Amended 16 of 2022 s. 59)

subsection.content: The right conferred by this section extends to the treatment of parts of a work resulting from a previous treatment by a person other than the author or director, if those parts are attributed to, or are likely to be regarded as the work of, the author or director.
This section has effect subject to sections 93 and 94 (exceptions to and qualifications of right).

section.name: s93
section.heading: Exceptions to right

subsection.content: The right conferred by section 92 (right to object to derogatory treatment of work) is subject to the following exceptions.
The right does not apply to a computer program or to any computer-generated work.
The right does not apply in relation to any work made for the purpose of reporting current events.

subsection.leadIn: The right does not apply in relation to the publication in—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a newspaper, magazine or similar periodical; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an encyclopaedia, dictionary, yearbook or other collective work of reference,

subsection.continued: of a literary, dramatic, musical or artistic work made for the purposes of such publication or made available with the consent of the author for the purposes of such publication.
Nor does the right apply in relation to any subsequent exploitation elsewhere of such a work without any modification of the published version.

subsection.content: The right is not infringed by an act which by virtue of section 66 or 75 (acts permitted on assumptions as to expiry of copyright, etc.) would not infringe copyright.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (7), the right is not infringed by anything done for the purpose of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: avoiding the commission of an offence; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: complying with a duty imposed by or under an enactment.

subsection.content: Where the author or director is identified at the time of the relevant act under subsection (6) or has previously been identified in or on published copies of the work, subsection (6) has effect only if there is a sufficient disclaimer.

section.name: s94
section.heading: Qualification of right in certain cases

subsection.leadIn: This section applies to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: works in which copyright originally vested in the author’s employer by virtue of section 14(1) (works produced in course of employment);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: works in which Government copyright or Legislative Council copyright subsists; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: works in which copyright originally vested in an international organization by virtue of section 188.

subsection.leadIn: The right conferred by section 92 (right to object to derogatory treatment of work) does not apply to anything done in relation to a work referred to in subsection (1) by or with the authority of the copyright owner unless the author or director—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is identified at the time of the relevant act; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: has previously been identified in or on published copies of the work,

subsection.continued: and where in such a case the right does apply, it is not infringed if there is a sufficient disclaimer.

section.name: s95
section.heading: Infringement of right by possessing or dealing with infringing article

subsection.leadIn: The right conferred by section 92 (right to object to derogatory treatment of work) is also infringed by a person who—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: possesses for the purpose of or in the course of any trade or business; (Replaced 64 of 2000 s. 4)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: sells or lets for hire, or offers or exposes for sale or hire;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: exhibits in public or distributes for the purpose of or in the course of any trade or business; or (Replaced 64 of 2000 s. 4)

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: distributes (otherwise than for the purpose of or in the course of any trade or business) so as to affect prejudicially the honour or reputation of the author or director, (Amended 64 of 2000 s. 4)

subsection.continued: an article which is, and which he knows or has reason to believe is, an infringing article. (Amended 15 of 2007 s.26)

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.content: It is immaterial for the purpose of subsection (1)(a) and (c) whether or not the trade or business consists of dealing in infringing articles. (Added 64 of 2000 s. 4)

def.name: InfringingArticle
def.leadIn: An infringing article (侵犯權利物品) means a work or a copy of a work which—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: has been subjected to derogatory treatment within the meaning of section 92; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: has been or is likely to be the subject of any of the acts mentioned in that section in circumstances infringing that right.

section.name: s96
section.heading: False attribution of work

subsection.leadIn: A person has the right in the circumstances mentioned in this section—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: not to have a literary, dramatic, musical or artistic work falsely attributed to him as author; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.text: not to have a film falsely attributed to him as director,

subsection.continued: and in this section an attribution (署名), in relation to such a work, means a statement (express or implied) as to who is the author or director.

subsection.leadIn: The right is infringed by a person who—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: issues to the public copies of a work of any of those descriptions in or on which there is a false attribution; or (Amended 16 of 2022 s. 60)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: exhibits in public an artistic work, or a copy of an artistic work, in or on which there is a false attribution.

subsection.leadIn: The right is also infringed by a person who—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the case of a literary, dramatic or musical work, performs the work in public or communicates it to the public as being the work of a person; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the case of a film, shows it in public or communicates it to the public as being directed by a person,

subsection.continued: knowing or having reason to believe that the attribution is false. (Amended 16 of 2022 s. 60)

subsection.content: The right is also infringed by a person who issues or makes available to the public or displays in public material containing a false attribution in connection with any of the acts mentioned in subsection (2) or (3).

subsection.leadIn: The right is also infringed by a person who for the purpose of or in the course of any trade or business— (Amended 64 of 2000 s. 5; 15 of 2007 s. 27)

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: in the case of an artistic work, possesses or deals with the work itself when there is a false attribution in or on it,

subsection.continued: knowing or having reason to believe that there is such an attribution and that it is false.

subsection.leadIn: In the case of an artistic work the right is also infringed by a person who for the purpose of or in the course of any trade or business— (Amended 64 of 2000 s. 5; 15 of 2007 s. 27)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: deals with a work which has been altered after the author parted with possession of it as being the unaltered work of the author; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: deals with a copy of such an altered work as being a copy of the unaltered work of the author,

subsection.continued: knowing or having reason to believe that that is not the case.

subsection.name: 6A
subsection.leadIn: It is immaterial for the purpose of subsections (5) and (6) whether or not the trade or business consists of dealing in—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: works or copies of works in or on which there are false attributions; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: altered works or copies of altered works. (Added 64 of 2000 s. 5)

subsection.content: References in this section to dealing are to selling or letting for hire, offering or exposing for sale or hire, exhibiting in public, or distributing.

subsection.leadIn: This section applies where, contrary to the fact—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a literary, dramatic or musical work is falsely represented as being an adaptation of the work of a person; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a copy of an artistic work is falsely represented as being a copy made by the author of the artistic work,

subsection.continued: as it applies where the work is falsely attributed to a person as author.

section.name: s97
section.heading: Duration of rights

subsection.content: The rights conferred by section 89 (right to be identified as author or director) and section 92 (right to object to derogatory treatment of work) continue to subsist so long as copyright subsists in the work.
The right conferred by section 96 (false attribution) continues to subsist until 20 years after a person’s death.

section.name: s98
section.heading: Consent and waiver of rights

subsection.content: It is not an infringement of any of the rights conferred by this Division to do any act to which the person entitled to the right has consented.
Any of those rights may be waived by instrument in writing signed by the person giving up the right.

subsection.leadIn: A waiver—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: may relate to a specific work, to works of a specified description or to works generally, and may relate to existing or future works; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: may be conditional or unconditional and may be expressed to be subject to revocation,

subsection.continued: and if made in favour of the owner or prospective owner of the copyright in the work or works to which it relates, it is presumed to extend to his licensees and successors in title unless a contrary intention is expressed.

subsection.content: Nothing in this Division is to be construed as excluding the operation of the general law of contract or estoppel in relation to an informal waiver or other transaction in relation to any of the rights mentioned in subsection (1).

section.name: s99
section.heading: Application of provisions to joint works

subsection.content: The right conferred by section 89 (right to be identified as author or director) is, in the case of a work of joint authorship, a right of each joint author to be identified as a joint author and must be asserted in accordance with section 90 by each joint author in relation to himself.

The right conferred by section 92 (right to object to derogatory treatment of work) is, in the case of a work of joint authorship, a right of each joint author and his right is satisfied if he consents to the treatment in question.
A waiver under section 98 of those rights by one joint author does not affect the rights of the other joint authors.

subsection.leadIn: The right conferred by section 96 (false attribution) is infringed, in the circumstances mentioned in that section—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: by any false statement as to the authorship of a work of joint authorship; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: by the false attribution of joint authorship in relation to a work of sole authorship,

subsection.continued: and such a false attribution infringes the right of every person to whom authorship of any description is, whether rightly or wrongly, attributed.

subsection.content: The provisions of this section also apply (with any necessary adaptations) in relation to a film which was, or is alleged to have been, jointly directed, as they apply to a work which is, or is alleged to be, a work of joint authorship.

A film is jointly directed (合作導演) if it is made by the collaboration of 2 or more directors and the contribution of each director is not distinct from that of the other director or directors. (Amended E.R. 2 of 2019)

section.name: s100
section.heading: Application of provisions to parts of works

subsection.content: The right conferred by section 89 (right to be identified as author or director) applies in relation to the whole or any substantial part of a work.
The rights conferred by section 92 (right to object to derogatory treatment of work) and section 96 (false attribution) apply in relation to the whole or any part of a work.

division.name: D5
division.heading: Dealings with Rights in Copyright Works

section.name: s101
section.heading: Assignment and licences

subsection.content: Copyright is transmissible by assignment, by testamentary disposition or by operation of law, as personal or moveable property.

subsection.leadIn: An assignment or other transmission of copyright may be partial, that is, limited so as to apply—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to one or more, but not all, of the things the copyright owner has the exclusive right to do;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to part, but not the whole, of the period for which the copyright is to subsist.

subsection.content: An assignment of copyright is not effective unless it is in writing signed by or on behalf of the assignor.

A licence granted by a copyright owner is binding on every successor in title to his interest in the copyright, except a purchaser in good faith for valuable consideration and without notice (actual or constructive) of the licence or a person deriving title from such a purchaser; and references in this Part to doing anything with, or without, the licence of the copyright owner are construed accordingly.

section.name: s102
section.heading: Prospective ownership of copyright

subsection.content: Without prejudice to sections 14 and 15, where by an agreement made in relation to future copyright, and signed by or on behalf of the prospective owner of the copyright, the prospective owner purports to assign the future copyright (wholly or partially) to another person, then if, on the copyright coming into existence, the assignee or another person claiming under him would be entitled as against all other persons to require the copyright to be vested in him, the copyright vests in the assignee or his successor in title by virtue of this subsection.

subsection.leadIn: In this Part—
subsection.def: future copyright (未來版權) means copyright which will or may come into existence in respect of a future work or class of works or on the occurrence of a future event; and
prospective owner (準擁有人) is construed accordingly, and includes a person who is prospectively entitled to copyright by virtue of such an agreement as is mentioned in subsection (1).

subsection.content: A licence granted by a prospective owner of copyright is binding on every successor in title to his interest (or prospective interest) in the right, except a purchaser in good faith for valuable consideration and without notice (actual or constructive) of the licence or a person deriving title from such a purchaser; and references in this Part to doing anything with, or without, the licence of the copyright owner are construed accordingly.

section.name: s103
section.heading: Exclusive licences

subsection.def: In this Part an exclusive licence (專用特許) means a licence in writing signed by or on behalf of the copyright owner authorizing the licensee to the exclusion of all other persons, including the person granting the licence, to exercise a right which would otherwise be exercisable exclusively by the copyright owner.

subsection.content: The licensee under an exclusive licence has the same rights against a successor in title who is bound by the licence as he has against the person granting the licence.

section.name: s104
section.heading: Copyright to pass under will with unpublished work
section.leadIn: Where under a bequest (whether specific or general) a person is entitled, beneficially or otherwise, to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an original document or other material thing recording or embodying a literary, dramatic, musical or artistic work which was not published before the death of the testator; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an original material thing containing a sound recording or film which was not published before the death of the testator,

section.continued: then unless a contrary intention is indicated in the testator’s will or a codicil to it, the bequest includes the copyright in the work in so far as the testator was the owner of the copyright immediately before his death.

section.name: s105
section.heading: Moral rights not assignable
section.content: The rights conferred by Division IV (moral rights) are not assignable.

section.name: s106
section.heading: Transmission of moral rights on death

subsection.leadIn: On the death of a person entitled to the right conferred by section 89 (right to identification of author or director) or section 92 (right to object to derogatory treatment of work)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the right passes to such a person as he may by testamentary disposition specifically direct;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if there is no such direction but the copyright in the work in question forms part of his estate, the right passes to the person to whom the copyright passes; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: if or to the extent that the right does not pass under paragraph (a) or (b) it is exercisable by his personal representatives.

subsection.leadIn: Where copyright forming part of a person’s estate passes in part to one person and in part to another, as for example where a bequest is limited so as to apply—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to one or more, but not all, of the things the copyright owner has the exclusive right to do or authorize; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to part, but not the whole, of the period for which the copyright is to subsist,

subsection.continued: any right which passes with the copyright by virtue of subsection (1) is correspondingly divided.

subsection.leadIn: Where by virtue of subsection (1)(a) or (b) a right becomes exercisable by more than one person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: it may, in the case of the right conferred by section 89 (right to identification of author or director), be asserted by any of them;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: it is, in the case of the right conferred by section 92 (right to object to derogatory treatment of work), a right exercisable by each of them and is satisfied in relation to any of them if he consents to the treatment or act in question; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: any waiver of the right in accordance with section 98 by one of them does not affect the rights of the others.

subsection.content: A consent or waiver previously given or made binds any person to whom a right passes by virtue of subsection (1).
Any infringement after a person’s death of the right conferred by section 96 (false attribution) is actionable by his personal representatives.

Any damages recovered by personal representatives by virtue of this section in respect of an infringement after a person’s death devolve as part of his estate as if the right of action had subsisted and been vested in him immediately before his death.

division.name: D6
division.heading: Remedies for Infringement
division.crossHeading: Rights and remedies of copyright owner

section.name: s107
section.heading: Infringement actionable by copyright owner

subsection.content: An infringement of copyright is actionable by the copyright owner.

In an action for infringement of copyright all such relief by way of damages, injunctions, accounts or otherwise is available to the plaintiff as is available in respect of the infringement of any other property right.
This section has effect subject to the following provisions of this Division.

section.name: s108
section.heading: Provisions as to damages in infringement action

subsection.content: Where in an action for infringement of copyright it is shown that at the time of the infringement the defendant did not know, and had no reason to believe, that copyright subsisted in the work to which the action relates, the plaintiff is not entitled to damages against him, but without prejudice to any other remedy.

subsection.leadIn: The court may in an action for infringement of copyright having regard to all the circumstances, and in particular to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the flagrancy of the infringement;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any benefit accruing to the defendant by reason of the infringement; (Amended 16 of 2022 s. 61)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the completeness, accuracy and reliability of the defendant’s business accounts and records; (Amended 16 of 2022 s. 61)

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: any unreasonable conduct of the defendant after the act constituting the infringement occurred, including any act done or attempt made by the defendant to destroy, conceal or disguise evidence of the infringement after having been informed of the infringement by the plaintiff; and (Added 16 of 2022 s. 61)

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: the likelihood of widespread circulation of infringing copies as a result of the infringement, (Added 16 of 2022 s. 61)

subsection.continued: award such additional damages as the justice of the case may require.

section.name: s109
section.heading: Order for delivery up

subsection.leadIn: Where a person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: has an infringing copy of a work in his possession, custody or control for the purpose of or in the course of any trade or business; or (Amended 64 of 2000 s. 6; 15 of 2007 s. 30)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: has in his possession, custody or control an article specifically designed or adapted for making copies of a particular copyright work, knowing or having reason to believe that it has been or is to be used to make infringing copies,

subsection.continued: the owner of the copyright in the work may apply to the court for an order that the infringing copy or article be delivered up to him or to such other person as the court may direct.

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.content: It is immaterial for the purpose of subsection (1)(a) whether or not the trade or business consists of dealing in infringing copies of copyright works. (Added 64 of 2000 s. 6)

An application must be made before the end of the period specified in section 110 (period after which remedy of delivery up not available); and the court shall not make an order under this section unless the court also makes, or it appears to the court that there are grounds for making, an order under section 111 (order as to disposal of infringing copy or other article).

A person to whom an infringing copy or other article is delivered up in pursuance of an order under this section shall, if an order under section 111 is not made, retain it pending the making of an order, or the decision not to make an order, under that section.
Nothing in this section affects any other power of the court.

section.name: s110
section.heading: Period after which remedy of delivery up not available

subsection.content: An application for an order under section 109 (order for delivery up in civil proceedings) may not be made after the end of the period of 6 years from the date on which the infringing copy or article in question was made, subject to the following provisions of this section.

subsection.leadIn: If during the whole or any part of that period the copyright owner—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is under a disability; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: is prevented by fraud or concealment from discovering the facts entitling him to apply for an order,

subsection.continued: an application may be made at any time before the end of the period of 6 years from the date on which he ceased to be under a disability or, as the case may be, could with reasonable diligence have discovered those facts.

subsection.def: In subsection (2) disability (無行為能力) has the same meaning as in the Limitation Ordinance (Cap. 347).

section.name: s111
section.heading: Order as to disposal of infringing copy or other article

subsection.leadIn: An application may be made to the court for an order that an infringing copy or other article delivered up in pursuance of an order under section 109 should be—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: forfeited to the copyright owner; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: destroyed or otherwise dealt with as the court may think fit,

subsection.continued: or for a decision that no such order should be made.

subsection.content: In considering what order (if any) should be made, the court shall consider whether other remedies available in an action for infringement of copyright would be adequate to compensate the copyright owner and to protect his interests.
The power to make rules of court under section 54 of the High Court Ordinance (Cap. 4) includes power to make rules of court for the purposes of this section. (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

subsection.leadIn: The rules of court made for the purposes of this section may include rules as to the service of notice on persons having an interest in the copy or other articles, and any such person is entitled—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to appear in proceedings for an order under this section, whether or not he was served with notice; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to appeal against any order made, whether or not he appeared.

subsection.content: An order under this section does not take effect until the end of the period within which notice of an appeal may be given or, if before the end of that period notice of appeal is duly given, until the final determination or abandonment of the proceedings on the appeal.

Where there is more than one person interested in a copy or other article, the court may make such order as it thinks just and may (in particular) direct that the copy or article be sold, or otherwise dealt with, and the proceeds divided.

If the court decides that no order should be made under this section, the person in whose possession, custody or control the copy or other article was before being delivered up is entitled to its return.

References in this section to a person having an interest in a copy or other article include any person in whose favour an order could be made in respect of it under this section or under section 231 (which makes similar provision in relation to infringement of rights in performances).

division.crossHeading: Rights and remedies of exclusive licensee

section.name: s112
section.heading: Rights and remedies of exclusive licensee

subsection.content: An exclusive licensee has, except against the copyright owner, the same rights and remedies in respect of matters occurring after the grant of the licence as if the licence had been an assignment.
His rights and remedies are concurrent with those of the copyright owner; and references in the relevant provisions of this Part to the copyright owner shall be construed accordingly.

In an action brought by an exclusive licensee by virtue of this section a defendant may avail himself of any defence which would have been available to him if the action had been brought by the copyright owner.

section.name: s113
section.heading: Exercise of concurrent rights

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (2), where an action for infringement of copyright brought by the copyright owner or an exclusive licensee relates (wholly or partly) to an infringement in respect of which they have concurrent rights of action, the copyright owner or, as the case may be, the exclusive licensee may not, without the leave of the court, proceed with the action unless the other is either joined as a plaintiff or added as a defendant.

Where an action for infringement of copyright brought by an exclusive licensee relates (wholly or partly) to an infringement in respect of an infringing copy within the meaning of section 35(3), the exclusive licensee may not, without the leave of the court, proceed with the action unless the copyright owner is joined as a plaintiff.

In an application for leave under subsection (2) to proceed without joining the copyright owner as plaintiff, the court shall not grant leave unless there are exceptional circumstances, other than costs considerations, beyond the control of the copyright owner or exclusive licensee.
A copyright owner or exclusive licensee who is added as a defendant in pursuance of subsection (1) is not liable for any costs in the action unless he takes part in the proceedings.
