The provisions of this section do not affect the granting of interlocutory relief on an application by a copyright owner or exclusive licensee alone.

subsection.leadIn: Where an action for infringement of copyright is brought which relates (wholly or partly) to an infringement in respect of which the copyright owner and an exclusive licensee have or had concurrent rights of action—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: the court shall in assessing damages take into account—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the terms of the licence; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: any pecuniary remedy already awarded or available to either of them in respect of the infringement;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the court shall not direct an account of profits if an award of damages has been made, or an account of profits has been directed, in favour of the other of them in respect of the infringement; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the court shall if an account of profits is directed apportion the profits between them as the court considers just, subject to any agreement between them,

subsection.continued: and these provisions apply whether or not the copyright owner and the exclusive licensee are both parties to the action.

subsection.content: The copyright owner shall notify any exclusive licensee having concurrent rights before applying for an order under section 109 (order for delivery up); and the court may on the application of the licensee make such order under section 109 as it thinks fit having regard to the terms of the licence.

division.crossHeading: Remedies for infringement of moral rights

section.name: s114
section.heading: Remedies for infringement of moral rights

subsection.content: An infringement of a right conferred by Division IV (moral rights) is actionable as a breach of statutory duty owed to the person entitled to the right.

In proceedings for infringement of the right conferred by section 92 (right to object to derogatory treatment of work) the court may, if it thinks it is an adequate remedy in the circumstances, grant an injunction on terms prohibiting the doing of any act unless a disclaimer is made, in such terms and in such manner as may be approved by the court, dissociating the author or director from the treatment of the work.

section.name: s115
section.heading: Presumptions relevant to literary, dramatic, musical and artistic works

subsection.content: The following presumptions apply in proceedings brought by virtue of this Division with respect to a literary, dramatic, musical or artistic work.

subsection.leadIn: Where a name purporting to be that of the author appeared on copies of the work as published or on the work when it was made, the person whose name appeared is presumed, until the contrary is proved—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to be the author of the work;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to have made it in circumstances not falling within section 14(1), 182, 184 or 188 (works produced in course of employment, Government copyright, Legislative Council copyright or copyright of certain international organizations).

subsection.content: In the case of a work alleged to be a work of joint authorship, subsection (2) applies in relation to each person alleged to be one of the authors.

Where no name purporting to be that of the author appeared as mentioned in subsection (2) but a name purporting to be that of the publisher appeared on copies of the work as first published, the person whose name appeared is presumed, until the contrary is proved, to have been the owner of the copyright at the time of publication.

subsection.leadIn: If the author of the work is dead or the identity of the author cannot be ascertained by reasonable inquiry, it is presumed, in the absence of evidence to the contrary—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that the work is an original work; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content:
that the plaintiff’s allegations as to what was the first publication of the work and as to country, territory or area
of first publication are correct. (Amended 31 of 2025 s. 151)

section.name: s116
section.heading: Presumptions relevant to sound recordings, films and computer programs

subsection.leadIn: In proceedings brought by virtue of this Division with respect to a sound recording, where copies of the recording as issued or made available to the public bear a label or other mark stating—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that a named person was the owner of copyright in the recording at the date of issue or making available of the copies; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: that the recording was first published in a specified year or in a specified country, territory or area, (Amended 31 of 2025 s. 152)

subsection.continued: the label or mark is admissible as evidence of the facts stated and is presumed to be correct until the contrary is proved.

subsection.leadIn: In proceedings brought by virtue of this Division with respect to a film, where copies of the film as issued or made available to the public bear a statement—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that a named person was the director or producer of the film;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: that a named person was the principal director, the author of the screenplay, the author of the dialogue or the composer of music specifically created for and used in the film;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: that a named person was the owner of copyright in the film at the date of issue or making available of the copies; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: that the film was first published in a specified year or in a specified country, territory or area, (Amended 31 of 2025 s. 152)

subsection.continued: the statement is admissible as evidence of the facts stated and is presumed to be correct until the contrary is proved.

subsection.leadIn: In proceedings brought by virtue of this Division with respect to a computer program, where copies of the program are issued to the public in electronic form or made available to the public bearing a statement—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that a named person was the owner of copyright in the program at the date of issue or making available of the copies; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: that the program was first published in a specified country, territory or area or that copies of it were first issued to the public in electronic form or made available to the public in a specified year, (Amended 31 of 2025 s. 152)

subsection.continued: the statement is admissible as evidence of the facts stated and is presumed to be correct until the contrary is proved.

subsection.content: The above presumptions apply equally in proceedings relating to an infringement alleged to have occurred before the date on which the copies were issued or made available to the public.

subsection.leadIn: In proceedings brought by virtue of this Division with respect to a film, where the film as shown in public or communicated to the public bears a statement— (Amended 16 of 2022 s. 62)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that a named person was the director or producer of the film;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: that a named person was the principal director of the film, the author of the screenplay, the author of the dialogue or the composer of music specifically created for and used in the film; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: that a named person was the owner of copyright in the film immediately after it was made,

subsection.continued: the statement is admissible as evidence of the facts stated and is presumed to be correct until the contrary is proved.

This presumption applies equally in proceedings relating to an infringement alleged to have occurred before the date on which the film was shown in public or communicated to the public. (Amended 16 of 2022 s. 62)

subsection.content: For the purposes of this section, a statement that a person was the director of a film is to be taken, unless a contrary indication appears, as meaning that he was the principal director of the film.

section.name: s117
section.heading: Presumptions relevant to works subject to Government copyright
section.content: In proceedings brought by virtue of this Division with respect to a literary, dramatic or musical work in which Government copyright subsists, where there appears on printed copies of the work a statement of the year in which the work was first published commercially, that statement is admissible as evidence of the fact stated and is presumed to be correct in the absence of evidence to the contrary.

section.name: s118
section.heading: Offences in relation to making or dealing with infringing articles, etc.

subsection.leadIn: A person commits an offence if he, without the licence of the copyright owner of a copyright work—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: makes for sale or hire an infringing copy of the work;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: imports an infringing copy of the work into Hong Kong otherwise than for his private and domestic use;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: exports an infringing copy of the work from Hong Kong otherwise than for his private and domestic use;

paragraph.name: d
e
f
paragraph.leadIn: possesses an infringing copy of the work with a view to—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: its being sold or let for hire by any person for the purpose of or in the course of any trade or business; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: its being exhibited in public or distributed by any person for the purpose of or in the course of any trade or business which consists of dealing in infringing copies of copyright works; or

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: distributes an infringing copy of the work (otherwise than for the purpose of or in the course of any trade or business which consists of dealing in infringing copies of copyright works) to such an extent as to affect prejudicially the copyright owner. (Replaced 15 of 2007 s. 31)

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.leadIn: Where—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: the circumstances in which the infringing copy is so exhibited or distributed give rise to a reasonable suspicion that the trade or business consists of dealing in infringing copies of copyright works,

subsection.continued: then, unless there is evidence to the contrary, the trade or business is presumed, for the purposes of any proceedings instituted under subsection (1)(e), to be a trade or business which consists of dealing in infringing copies of copyright works. (Added 15 of 2007 s. 31)

subsection.name: 1B
subsection.leadIn: Where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a person possesses an infringing copy of a copyright work with a view to its being exhibited in public or distributed by any person for the purpose of or in the course of any trade or business; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the circumstances in which the infringing copy is so possessed give rise to a reasonable suspicion that the trade or business consists of dealing in infringing copies of copyright works,

subsection.continued: then, unless there is evidence to the contrary, the trade or business is presumed, for the purposes of any proceedings instituted under subsection (1)(f)(ii), to be a trade or business which consists of dealing in infringing copies of copyright works. (Added 15 of 2007 s. 31)

subsection.content: Subsections (1)(b) and (c) and (4)(b) and (c) do not apply to an article in transit.

subsection.name: 2AA
subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (1)(g), in determining whether any distribution of an infringing copy of the work is made to such an extent as to affect prejudicially the copyright owner, the court—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: may take into account all the circumstances of the case; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in particular, may take into account whether economic prejudice is caused to the copyright owner as a consequence of the distribution, having regard to whether the infringing copy so distributed amounts to a substitution for the work. (Added 16 of 2022 s. 63)

subsection.name: 2A
subsection.content: A person commits an offence if he, without the licence of the copyright owner of a copyright work to which this subsection applies, possesses an infringing copy of the work for the purpose of or in the course of any trade or business with a view to its being used by any person for the purpose of or in the course of that trade or business. (Added 15 of 2007 s. 31)

subsection.name: 2B
subsection.leadIn: Subsection (2A) applies to a copyright work that is—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a computer program;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a movie;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a television drama;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: a musical sound recording; or

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: a musical visual recording. (Added 15 of 2007 s. 31)

subsection.name: 2C
subsection.content: Subsection (2A) does not apply to an infringing copy of a computer program in a printed form. (Added 15 of 2007 s. 31)

subsection.name: 2D
subsection.leadIn: Subsection (2A) does not apply to the possession of an infringing copy of a computer program if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the computer program incorporates the whole or any part of a work that is not a computer program itself, and the computer program is technically required for the viewing or listening of the work by a member of the public to whom a copy of the work is made available; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the computer program is incorporated in a work that is not a computer program itself, and the computer program is technically required for the viewing or listening of the work by a member of the public to whom a copy of the work is made available. (Added 15 of 2007 s. 31)

subsection.name: 2E
subsection.leadIn: Subsection (2A) does not apply to the possession of an infringing copy of a movie, television drama, musical sound recording or musical visual recording by a designated library, museum or archive for the purpose of heritage conservation if— (Amended 16 of 2022 s. 63)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the infringing copy was donated or given to the library, museum or archive by the public; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the infringing copy was made by the library, museum or archive to preserve or replace the infringing copy referred to in paragraph (a) against loss, deterioration or damage. (Added 15 of 2007 s. 31. Amended 16 of 2022 s. 63)

subsection.name: 2F
subsection.leadIn: Subsection (2A) does not apply to the possession of an infringing copy of a movie, television drama, musical sound recording or musical visual recording by a designated library, museum or archive for the purpose of doing any act in relation to the infringing copy (other than for the purpose referred to in subsection (2E)) if— (Amended 16 of 2022 s. 63)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: the infringing copy was—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: an infringing copy donated or given to the library, museum or archive by the public; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: an infringing copy made by the library, museum or archive to preserve or replace the infringing copy referred to in subparagraph (i) against loss, deterioration or damage; (Amended 16 of 2022 s. 63)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: it is not possible by reasonable enquiry to ascertain the identity and contact details of the copyright owner of the work in question; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a copy (other than an infringing copy) of the work in question cannot be obtained on reasonable commercial terms. (Added 15 of 2007 s. 31)

subsection.name: 2FA
subsection.leadIn: In subsections (2E) and (2F), references to a designated library, museum or archive are references to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a library, museum or archive owned by the Government; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a library, museum or archive designated by the Secretary for Commerce and Economic Development under subsection (2FB). (Added 16 of 2022 s. 63)

subsection.name: 2FB
subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (2FA)(b), the Secretary for Commerce and Economic Development may, having regard to the advice of the Director of Leisure and Cultural Services, by notice published in the Gazette, designate any library, museum or archive that is—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: owned by a charitable institution or trust of a public character that is exempt from tax under section 88 of the Inland Revenue Ordinance (Cap. 112) (Cap. 112); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: owned by—

subparagraph.content: a statutory body that is exempt from tax under an Ordinance other than Cap. 112; or
a subsidiary of such a statutory body. (Added 16 of 2022 s. 63)

subsection.name: 2FC
subsection.leadIn: In subsection (2FB)(b)—
subsection.def: statutory body (法定團體) means a body established or constituted by or under the authority of an Ordinance;
subsidiary (附屬公司) has the meaning given by section 15 of the Companies Ordinance (Cap. 622). (Added 16 of 2022 s. 63)

subsection.name: 2G
subsection.leadIn: Subsection (2A) does not apply if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: the person who possesses an infringing copy does so for the purpose of providing legal service in relation to the infringing copy, and—

subparagraph.name: i
ii
subparagraph.content: the person has been admitted as a legal practitioner in a jurisdiction other than Hong Kong;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the person who possesses an infringing copy is serving a pupillage under the Barristers (Qualification for Admission and Pupillage) Rules (Cap. 159 sub. leg. AC) and he possesses the infringing copy for the purpose of assisting the barrister with whom he serves the pupillage in providing legal service in relation to the infringing copy;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the person who possesses an infringing copy does so for the purpose of providing investigation service in relation to the infringing copy to the copyright owner or exclusive licensee of the copyright work concerned; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the person who possesses an infringing copy does so on his client’s premises and the infringing copy is provided to him by his client. (Added 15 of 2007 s. 31)

subsection.name: 2H
subsection.leadIn: Without prejudice to section 125, where a body corporate or a partnership has done an act referred to in subsection (2A), the following person shall, unless there is evidence showing that he did not authorize the act to be done, be presumed also to have done the act—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: in the case of the body corporate—

subparagraph.name: i
ii
subparagraph.content: if there was no such director, any person who, at the time when the act was done, was responsible under the immediate authority of the directors of the body corporate for the internal management of the body corporate;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: in the case of the partnership—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: any partner in the partnership who, at the time when the act was done, was responsible for the internal management of the partnership; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: if there was no such partner, any person who, at the time when the act was done, was responsible under the immediate authority of the partners in the partnership for the internal management of the partnership. (Added 15 of 2007 s. 31)

subsection.name: 2I
subsection.leadIn: A defendant charged with an offence under subsection (2A) by virtue of subsection (2H) is taken not to have done the act in question if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: sufficient evidence is adduced to raise an issue that he did not authorize the act to be done; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the contrary is not proved by the prosecution beyond reasonable doubt. (Added 15 of 2007 s. 31)

subsection.name: 2J
subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (2I)(a)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: the defendant shall be taken to have adduced sufficient evidence if the court is satisfied that—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the defendant has caused the body corporate or partnership concerned to set aside financial resources, and has directed the use of the resources, for the acquisition of a sufficient number of copies of the copyright work to which the proceedings relate, which are not infringing copies, for the use of the body corporate or partnership; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the body corporate or partnership concerned has incurred expenditure for the acquisition of a sufficient number of copies of the copyright work to which the proceedings relate, which are not infringing copies, for the use of the body corporate or partnership;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: subject to paragraph (a), in determining whether sufficient evidence is adduced, the court may have regard to, including but not limited to, the following—

subparagraph.name: i
ii
subparagraph.content: whether the defendant has taken action to prevent the use of infringing copies of copyright works by the body corporate or partnership. (Added 15 of 2007 s. 31)

subsection.content: It is a defence for the person charged with an offence under subsection (1) or (2A), to prove that he did not know and had no reason to believe that the copy in question was an infringing copy of the copyright work. (Amended 15 of 2007 s. 31)

subsection.name: 3A
subsection.leadIn: It is a defence for the person charged with an offence under subsection (2A) to prove that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: he possessed the infringing copy in question in the course of his employment; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the infringing copy in question was provided to him by or on behalf of his employer for use in the course of his employment. (Added 15 of 2007 s. 31)

subsection.name: 3B
subsection.leadIn: Subsection (3A) does not apply to an employee—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: who, at the time when the infringing copy in question was acquired, was in a position to make or influence a decision regarding the acquisition of the infringing copy; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: who, at the time when the offence in question was committed, was in a position to make or influence a decision regarding the use or removal of the infringing copy in question. (Added 15 of 2007 s. 31)

subsection.leadIn: A person commits an offence if he—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: makes;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: imports into Hong Kong;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: exports from Hong Kong;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: possesses; or

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: sells or lets for hire, or offers or exposes for sale or hire,

subsection.continued: an article specifically designed or adapted for making copies of a particular copyright work which article is used or intended to be used to make infringing copies of the copyright work for sale or hire or for use for the purpose of or in the course of any trade or business. (Amended 64 of 2000 s. 7; 15 of 2007 s. 31)

subsection.content: It is a defence for the person charged with an offence under subsection (4) to prove that he did not know and had no reason to believe that the article was used or was intended to be used to make the infringing copies for sale or hire or for use for the purpose of or in the course of any trade or business. (Amended 64 of 2000 s. 7; 15 of 2007 s. 31)

subsection.leadIn: For the purpose of subsections (1)(b) and (3), where a person is charged with an offence under subsection (1) in respect of a copy of a copyright work which is an infringing copy by virtue only of section 35(3) and not being excluded under section 35(4) and which was lawfully made in the country, territory or area where it was made, if he proves that— (Amended 15 of 2007 s. 31)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: he had made reasonable enquiries sufficient to satisfy himself that the copy in question was not an infringing copy of the work;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: he had reasonable grounds to be satisfied in the circumstances of the case that the copy was not an infringing copy;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: there were no other circumstances which would have led him reasonably to suspect that the copy was an infringing copy,

subsection.continued: he has proved that he had no reason to believe that the copy in question was an infringing copy of the copyright work.

subsection.leadIn: In determining whether the person charged has proved under subsection (6) that he had no reason to believe that the copy in question was an infringing copy of the work, the court may have regard to, including but not limited to, the following—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: whether he had made enquiries with a relevant trade body in respect of that category of work;

paragraph.name: b
c
paragraph.content: whether he had complied with any code of practice that may exist in respect of the supply of that category of work;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: whether the response, if any, to those enquiries made by the defendant was reasonable and timely;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: whether he was provided with the name, address and contact details of the copyright owner or exclusive licensee (as the case may be);

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: whether he was provided with the date of first day of publication of the work;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: whether he was provided with proof of any relevant exclusive licence.

subsection.content: A person commits an offence if he has in his possession an article knowing or having reason to believe that it is used or is intended to be used to make infringing copies of any copyright work for sale or hire or for use for the purpose of or in the course of any trade or business. (Amended 64 of 2000 s. 7; 15 of 2007 s. 31)

subsection.name: 8B
subsection.leadIn: A person commits an offence if the person infringes copyright in a work by—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: communicating the work to the public for the purpose of or in the course of any trade or business that consists of communicating works to the public for profit or reward; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: communicating the work to the public (otherwise than for the purpose of or in the course of any trade or business that consists of communicating works to the public for profit or reward) to such an extent as to affect prejudicially the copyright owner. (Added 16 of 2022 s. 63)

subsection.name: 8C
subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (8B)(b), in determining whether any communication of the work to the public is made to such an extent as to affect prejudicially the copyright owner, the court—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: may take into account all the circumstances of the case; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in particular, may take into account whether economic prejudice is caused to the copyright owner as a consequence of the communication, having regard to whether the communication amounts to a substitution for the work. (Added 16 of 2022 s. 63)

subsection.name: 8D
subsection.content: It is a defence for the person charged with an offence under subsection (8B) to prove that the person did not know and had no reason to believe that, by communicating the work in question in the circumstances described in subsection (8B)(a) or (b), the person was infringing the copyright in the work. (Added 16 of 2022 s. 63)
Sections 115 to 117 (presumptions as to various matters connected with copyright) do not apply to proceedings for an offence under this section.

subsection.def: In this section, dealing in (經銷) means selling, letting for hire, or distributing for profit or reward. (Added 15 of 2007 s. 31)

section.name: s118A
section.heading: Application of sections 60 and 61 to offences under section 118(1)
section.leadIn: For the purpose of any proceedings for an offence under section 118(1)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a person is a lawful user of a computer program for the purposes of sections 60 and 61 if he has a contractual right to use the program in any place in or outside Hong Kong, and section 60(2) shall have effect accordingly; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: sections 60 and 61 apply in relation to a copy of a work other than a computer program to which section 35A(1) applies as they apply in relation to a copy of a computer program and, accordingly, any act that may under section 60 or 61 be done in relation to a copy of a computer program without infringing the copyright in the program may be done in relation to a copy of a work other than a computer program to which section 35A(1) applies without infringing the copyright in the work.

section.name: s119
section.heading: Penalties for offences under section 118

subsection.content: A person who commits an offence under section 118(1) or (2A) is liable on conviction on indictment to a fine at level 5 in respect of each infringing copy and to imprisonment for 4 years. (Amended 64 of 2000 s. 8; 15 of 2007 s. 32)
A person who commits an offence under section 118(4) or (8) is liable on conviction on indictment to a fine of $500,000 and to imprisonment for 8 years.

A person who commits an offence under section 118(8B) is liable on conviction on indictment to a fine at level 5 in respect of each copyright work and to imprisonment for 4 years. (Added 16 of 2022 s. 64)

section.name: s119A
section.heading: Offence in relation to possession of infringing copies in a copying service business

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: copying service business (複製服務業務) means a business, conducted for profit, that includes the offering of reprographic copying services to the public and, in the case of a business that includes the offering of reprographic copying services to the public at more than one place, means any part of the business carried on at such a place;
reward (報酬) means reward other than reward of a nominal value.

subsection.content: A person commits an offence if, for the purpose of or in the course of a copying service business, he possesses a reprographic copy of a copyright work as published in a book, magazine or periodical, being a copy that is an infringing copy of the copyright work.

In proceedings for an offence under subsection (2), it is a defence for the person charged to prove that the infringing copy of a copyright work in question was not made for the purpose of and was not made in the course of the copying service business.

In proceedings for an offence under subsection (2), it is a defence for the person charged to prove that the infringing copy of a copyright work in question was not made for profit and was not made for reward.

In proceedings for an offence under subsection (2), it is a defence for the person charged to prove that he did not know and had no reason to believe that the copy of a copyright work in question was an infringing copy of the copyright work.
A person who commits an offence under subsection (2) is liable on conviction on indictment to a fine at level 5 in respect of each infringing copy and to imprisonment for 4 years.
Sections 115, 116 and 117 (presumptions as to various matters connected with copyright) do not apply to proceedings for an offence under subsection (2).

section.name: s119B
section.heading: Offence in relation to making for distribution or distributing on a regular or frequent basis infringing copies of copyright works in printed form contained in books, etc.

subsection.leadIn: A person commits an offence if he does any of the following acts on a regular or frequent basis for the purpose of or in the course of any trade or business—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: without the licence of the copyright owner of a copyright work described in subsection (2), makes an infringing copy of the work for distribution, resulting in a financial loss to the copyright owner; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: without the licence of the copyright owner of a copyright work described in subsection (2), distributes an infringing copy of the work, resulting in a financial loss to the copyright owner.

subsection.leadIn: The copyright work referred to in subsection (1)(a) and (b) is a copyright work in a printed form that is contained in—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a book;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a magazine;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a periodical; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: a newspaper.

subsection.content: Subsection (1) does not apply in the circumstances described in Schedules 1AA and 1AB. (Replaced 15 of 2009 s. 3)

subsection.leadIn: Subsection (1) does not apply to an educational establishment of any of the following descriptions—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an educational establishment specified in section 1 of Schedule 1;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an educational establishment exempt from tax under section 88 of the Inland Revenue Ordinance (Cap. 112); or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: an educational establishment receiving direct recurrent subvention from the Government.

subsection.content: Subsection (1) does not apply to the distribution through a wire or wireless network of an infringing copy to which access is not restricted by procedures of authentication or identification.

subsection.leadIn: Subsection (1) does not apply if the infringing copy—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: forms part of the special collection of a library or archive owned by the Government, or a library or archive designated under subsection (10)(a); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: is distributed solely—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: for on-the-spot reference use in, or during an activity organized by, a library or archive referred to in paragraph (a); or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: for loan to other libraries or archives for the purpose of exhibition or research.

subsection.content: Subsection (1) does not apply to the making or distribution by a library or archive referred to in subsection (6)(a) of a single copy of any item forming the special collection for the purpose of preserving or replacing the item against loss, deterioration or damage, but the copy may only be distributed for the use referred to in subsection (6)(b).

def.name: SpecialCollection
def.leadIn: In subsections (6) and (7), special collection (特別收藏品)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the case of a library or archive owned by the Government, means a collection consisting primarily of works or articles, or copies of works or articles, donated or given by the public that are, in the opinion of the Director of Leisure and Cultural Services, of cultural, historical or heritage importance or value;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the case of a library or archive designated under subsection (10)(a), means a collection consisting primarily of works or articles, or copies of works or articles, donated or given by the public that are, in the opinion of the head or controlling body (by whatever name called) of the library or archive, of cultural, historical or heritage importance or value.

subsection.content: For the purposes of the exception under subsections (6) and (7), an archive owned by the Government includes a museum owned by the Government.

subsection.leadIn: The Secretary for Commerce and Economic Development may, having regard to the advice of the Director of Leisure and Cultural Services—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: by notice published in the Gazette designate for the purposes of subsection (6)(a) any library or archive that is exempt from tax under section 88 of the Inland Revenue Ordinance (Cap. 112); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: by regulations prescribe the conditions that a library or archive designated under paragraph (a) must comply in order to be eligible for the exemption provided by subsections (6) and (7).

subsection.leadIn: Without prejudice to section 125, where a body corporate or a partnership has done an act referred to in subsection (1), the following person shall, unless there is evidence showing that he did not authorize the act to be done, be presumed also to have done the act—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: in the case of the body corporate—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: any director of the body corporate who, at the time when the act was done, was responsible for the internal management of the body corporate; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: if there was no such director, any person who, at the time when the act was done, was responsible under the immediate authority of the directors of the body corporate for the internal management of the body corporate;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: in the case of the partnership—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: any partner in the partnership who, at the time when the act was done, was responsible for the internal management of the partnership; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: if there was no such partner, any person who, at the time when the act was done, was responsible under the immediate authority of the partners in the partnership for the internal management of the partnership.

subsection.leadIn: A defendant charged with an offence under subsection (1) by virtue of subsection (11) is taken not to have done the act in question if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: sufficient evidence is adduced to raise an issue that he did not authorize the act to be done; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the contrary is not proved by the prosecution beyond reasonable doubt.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (12)(a)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: the defendant shall be taken to have adduced sufficient evidence if the court is satisfied that—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the defendant has caused the body corporate or partnership concerned to set aside financial resources, and has directed the use of the resources, for the acquisition of appropriate licences, in accordance with the needs of the body corporate or partnership, to make or distribute, or to make and distribute, copies of the copyright work to which the proceedings relate for the use of the body corporate or partnership;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the defendant has caused the body corporate or partnership concerned to set aside financial resources, and has directed the use of the resources, for the acquisition of a sufficient number of copies of the copyright work to which the proceedings relate, which are not infringing copies, for the use of the body corporate or partnership;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: the body corporate or partnership concerned has incurred expenditure for the acquisition of appropriate licences, in accordance with the needs of the body corporate or partnership, to make or distribute, or to make and distribute, copies of the copyright work to which the proceedings relate for the use of the body corporate or partnership; or

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.content: the body corporate or partnership concerned has incurred expenditure for the acquisition of a sufficient number of copies of the copyright work to which the proceedings relate, which are not infringing copies, for the use of the body corporate or partnership;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: subject to paragraph (a), in determining whether sufficient evidence is adduced, the court may have regard to, including but not limited to, the following—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: whether the defendant has introduced policies or practices against the making and distribution of infringing copies of copyright works by the body corporate or partnership;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: whether the defendant has taken action to prevent the making or distribution of infringing copies of copyright works by the body corporate or partnership.

subsection.leadIn: It is a defence for the person charged with an offence under subsection (1) to prove that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: he has taken adequate and reasonable steps to obtain a licence from the copyright owner in question but failed to get a timely response from the copyright owner;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: he has made reasonable efforts but failed to obtain commercially available copies of the copyright work in question and the copyright owner in question has refused to grant him a licence on reasonable commercial terms;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: he did not know and had no reason to believe that the copies made or distributed are infringing copies; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: he cannot, after making reasonable enquiries, ascertain the identity and contact details of the copyright owner in question.

subsection.leadIn: It is a defence for the person charged with an offence in respect of an act under subsection (1) to prove that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: he did the act in the course of his employment; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: he did the act in accordance with the instruction given to him by or on behalf of his employer in the course of his employment.

subsection.content: Subsection (15) does not apply to an employee who, at the time when the infringing copy in question was made or distributed, was in a position to make or influence a decision regarding the making or distribution of the infringing copy.
A person who commits an offence under subsection (1) is liable on conviction on indictment to a fine at level 5 in respect of each infringing copy and to imprisonment for 4 years.
Sections 115 and 117 (presumptions as to various matters connected with copyright) do not apply to proceedings for an offence under subsection (1).
The Secretary for Commerce and Economic Development may, by notice published in the Gazette, amend Schedules 1AA and 1AB. (Added 15 of 2009 s. 3)

section.name: s120
section.heading: Making infringing copies outside Hong Kong, etc.

subsection.content: A person commits an offence if he makes outside Hong Kong, for export to Hong Kong otherwise than for his private and domestic use, any article that he knows would, if it were made in Hong Kong, constitute an infringing copy of a copyright work.

A person commits an offence if he makes outside Hong Kong an article specifically designed or adapted for making copies of a particular copyright work knowing or having reason to believe that it is to be used or is intended to be used in Hong Kong for making an infringing copy of the copyright work for sale or hire or for use for the purpose of or in the course of any trade or business. (Amended 64 of 2000 s. 9; 15 of 2007 s. 34)

subsection.name: 2A
subsection.content: It is immaterial for the purpose of subsection (2) whether or not the trade or business consists of dealing in infringing copies of copyright works. (Added 64 of 2000 s. 9)

subsection.leadIn: A person commits an offence if he makes outside Hong Kong or exports from Hong Kong an article specifically designed or adapted for making copies of a particular copyright work, knowing or having reason to believe that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the article is to be used or is intended to be used outside Hong Kong for making another article for export to Hong Kong; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the latter article mentioned in paragraph (a) would, if it were made in Hong Kong, constitute an infringing copy of the copyright work.

subsection.content: A person who, in Hong Kong or elsewhere, aids, abets, counsels or procures the commission by another person of an offence under subsection (1), (2) or (3) commits that offence as a principal.
The offences under subsections (1), (2) and (3) are without prejudice to the offences under section 118.
A person who commits an offence under subsection (1), (2) or (3) is liable on conviction on indictment to a fine of $500,000 and to imprisonment for 8 years.

subsection.def: For the purpose of this section, article (物品) does not include an article in transit.

subsection.content: Sections 115 to 117 (presumptions as to various matters connected with copyright) do not apply to proceedings for an offence under this section.

section.name: s120A
section.heading: Time limit for prosecutions
section.content: No prosecution for an offence under this Ordinance shall be commenced after the expiration of 3 years from the date of commission of the offence.

section.name: s121
section.heading: Affidavit evidence

subsection.leadIn: For the purpose of facilitating the proof of subsistence and ownership of copyright, and without prejudice to the operation of sections 11 to 16 (authorship and ownership of copyright) and sections 17 to 21 (duration of copyright), an affidavit which purports to have been made by or on behalf of the copyright owner of a copyright work and which states— (Amended 15 of 2007 s. 36)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the date and place that the work was made or first published;

paragraph.name: b
ba
paragraph.leadIn: where the author of the work is an individual—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the place of domicile of the author;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the place of residence of the author; or

subparagraph.name: iii

paragraph.name: bb
paragraph.leadIn: where the author of the work is a body corporate—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the place of incorporation of the author; or

subparagraph.name: ii

paragraph.name: c
d
paragraph.content: that copyright subsists in the work; and

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: that a copy of the work exhibited to the affidavit is a true copy of the work,

subsection.continued: shall, subject to the conditions contained in subsection (4), be admitted without further proof in any proceedings under this Ordinance.

subsection.leadIn: For the purpose of facilitating the proof of subsistence and ownership of copyright, and without prejudice to subsection (1) and the operation of sections 11 to 16 (authorship and ownership of copyright) and sections 17 to 21 (duration of copyright), an affidavit which purports to have been made by or on behalf of the copyright owner of a copyright work and which— (Amended 15 of 2007 s. 36)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: states—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: that the copyright work has been registered with a Copyright Register prescribed under subsection (16); and (Amended L.N. 29 of 2004)

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: that copyright subsists in the work; and

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: the name of the copyright owner; and (Amended 15 of 2007 s. 36)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: has exhibited to it a copy of the certificate of registration of the work issued by the authority in charge of the Copyright Register certified to be a true copy by a person specified in subsection (4)(a),

subsection.continued: shall, subject to the conditions contained in subsection (4), be admitted without further proof in any proceedings under this Ordinance.

subsection.name: 2A
subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of facilitating the establishment of the matter referred to in section 35(3)(b), an affidavit which purports to have been made by or on behalf of the copyright owner of a copyright work and which—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: states the name of the copyright owner;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: states that a copy of the work exhibited to the affidavit is a true copy of the work;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: states—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: that the copy of the work exhibited to the affidavit was made in a place outside Hong Kong by the copyright owner; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: that the copy of the work exhibited to the affidavit was made in a place outside Hong Kong by a person who has the licence of the copyright owner to make copies of the work in that place, but does not have the licence of the copyright owner to make copies of the work in Hong Kong; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: states the name and address of the person (if any) referred to in paragraph (c)(ii),

subsection.continued: shall, subject to the conditions contained in subsection (4), be admitted without further proof in any proceedings under this Ordinance. (Added 15 of 2007 s. 36)

subsection.name: 2B
subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of any proceedings instituted under section 118(1), an affidavit which purports to have been made by or on behalf of the copyright owner of a copyright work and which—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: states the name of the copyright owner; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: states that the person named in the affidavit does not have the licence of the copyright owner to do an act referred to in section 118(1)(a), (b), (c), (d), (e), (f) or (g) in respect of the work,

subsection.continued: shall, subject to the conditions contained in subsection (4), be admitted without further proof in those proceedings. (Added 15 of 2007 s. 36)

subsection.name: 2C
subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of any proceedings instituted under section 118(2A), an affidavit which purports to have been made by or on behalf of the copyright owner of a copyright work and which—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: states the name of the copyright owner; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: states that the person named in the affidavit does not have the licence of the copyright owner to do an act referred to in section 118(2A) in respect of the work,

subsection.continued: shall, subject to the conditions contained in subsection (4), be admitted without further proof in those proceedings. (Added 15 of 2007 s. 36)

subsection.name: 2CA
subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of any proceedings instituted under section 118(8B), an affidavit that purports to have been made by or on behalf of the copyright owner of a copyright work and that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: states the name of the copyright owner; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: states that the person named in the affidavit does not have the licence of the copyright owner to do an act referred to in that section in respect of the work,

subsection.continued: is, subject to the conditions contained in subsection (4), to be admitted without further proof in the proceedings. (Added 16 of 2022 s. 65)

subsection.name: 2D
subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of any proceedings instituted under section 119B(1), an affidavit which purports to have been made by or on behalf of the copyright owner of a copyright work and which—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: states the name of the copyright owner; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: states that the person named in the affidavit does not have the licence of the copyright owner to do an act referred to in section 119B(1) in respect of the work,

subsection.continued: shall, subject to the conditions contained in subsection (4), be admitted without further proof in those proceedings. (Added 15 of 2007 s. 36)

subsection.leadIn: The court before whom an affidavit which complies with the conditions in subsection (4) is produced under subsection (1), (2), (2A), (2B), (2C), (2CA) or (2D) shall presume, in the absence of evidence to the contrary— (Amended 15 of 2007 s. 36; 16 of 2022 s. 65)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that the statements made in the affidavit are true; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: that it was made and authenticated in accordance with subsection (4).

subsection.leadIn: An affidavit may be tendered in evidence under subsection (1), (2), (2A), (2B), (2C), (2CA) or (2D) if— (Amended 15 of 2007 s. 36; 16 of 2022 s. 65)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: it is made on oath—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: before a solicitor or a commissioner as defined in the Oaths and Declarations Ordinance (Cap. 11), if it is made in Hong Kong; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: before a notary public, if it is made outside Hong Kong;

paragraph.name: b
c
paragraph.content: it contains a declaration by the deponent to the effect that it is true to the best of his knowledge and belief; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: subject to subsection (6), not less than 10 days before the commencement of the hearing at which the affidavit is tendered in evidence, a copy of the affidavit is served, by or on behalf of the prosecution or plaintiff, on each of the defendants.

subsection.content: Notwithstanding that an affidavit is admissible as evidence by virtue of this section, a defendant or his solicitor may, within 3 days from the service of the copy of the affidavit, serve a notice requiring the attendance of the deponent to the affidavit in court.
The parties may agree before the hearing that the requirements of subsection (4)(d) may be dispensed with.

subsection.leadIn: If an affidavit tendered in evidence under subsection (1), (2), (2A), (2B), (2C), (2CA) or (2D)— (Amended 15 of 2007 s. 36; 16 of 2022 s. 65)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is made in a language other than English or Chinese, it must be accompanied by an English or Chinese translation thereof and, unless otherwise agreed by or on behalf of the prosecutor or plaintiff and defendant (or, if more than one, all the defendants), the translation must be certified by the court translator;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: refers to any other document as an exhibit, the copy served on any other party to the proceedings under subsection (4)(d) must be accompanied by a copy of that document or by such information as may be necessary in order to enable the party on whom it is served to inspect that document or a copy thereof.

subsection.leadIn: Without prejudice to subsection (5)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the party by whom or on whose behalf the affidavit was served may call the deponent to give evidence; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the court may of its own motion or, if the defendant who has served a notice under subsection (5) in relation to an affidavit satisfies the court—

subparagraph.name: i
ii
subparagraph.content: that whether a person has the licence of the copyright owner of a copyright work to do a particular act is, insofar as that matter is stated in the affidavit, genuinely in issue; or

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: where the affidavit is made under subsection (2A), that any matter stated in the affidavit, other than those referred to in subparagraphs (i) and (ii), is genuinely in issue,

paragraph.continued: either before or during the hearing, require the deponent to the affidavit to attend before the court and give evidence. (Replaced 15 of 2007 s. 36)

subsection.content: Without prejudice to subsection (8)(a), a deponent of an affidavit which is admissible under this section shall attend before the court and give evidence if, and only if, the court so requires under subsection (8)(b).

So much of an affidavit as is admitted in evidence by virtue of this section is, unless the court otherwise directs, to be read aloud at the hearing and where the court so directs an account is to be given orally of so much of any affidavit as is not read aloud.

Any document or object referred to as an exhibit and identified in an affidavit admitted in evidence under this section is treated as if it had been produced as an exhibit and identified in court by the deponent.

subsection.leadIn: A document required by this section to be served on any person may be served—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: by delivering it to him or to his solicitor; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the case of a body corporate, by delivering it to the secretary or clerk of the body at its registered or principal office or by sending it by registered post addressed to the secretary or clerk of that body at that office.

subsection.leadIn: Without prejudice to the powers of the court to award costs, the court may award costs against a defendant who—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: was served with an affidavit described in subsection (1), (2), (2A), (2B), (2C), (2CA) or (2D); (Amended 15 of 2007 s. 36; 16 of 2022 s. 65)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: by himself or through his solicitor served a notice under subsection (5); and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: was subsequently convicted of the relevant offence or found liable for the infringement, as the case may be.

subsection.content: In awarding awards under subsection (13), the court shall have regard to the actual costs incurred by the prosecution or plaintiff as a result of the notice under subsection (5) served by the defendant and the court may award costs under subsection (13) exceeding the limit of costs, if any, which that court may award.

For the purpose of subsection (1)(e), where the work is a computer program, whether in source codes or object codes, a copy of the program only in the form of object codes is also regarded as a true copy of the program.

The Secretary for Commerce and Economic Development may by regulation prescribe the Copyright Registers for the purpose of subsection (2). (Amended L.N. 173 of 2000; L.N. 106 of 2002; L.N. 130 of 2007)
In this section, court (法院) includes a magistrate.

section.name: s122
section.heading: Powers of investigating officers

subsection.leadIn: An authorized officer may—

paragraph.name: a

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: subject to section 123, enter and search any place; (Amended 22 of 1998 s. 45)

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: stop, board and search any vessel (other than a ship of war) or any aircraft (other than a military aircraft); or

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: stop and search any vehicle (other than a military vehicle),

paragraph.leadIn: in which he reasonably suspects that there is—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: an article which is an infringing copy of a copyright work;

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: an article specifically designed or adapted for making copies of a particular copyright work which article is used or intended to be used for making infringing copies of any such work; or

subparagraph.name: C
subparagraph.content: anything which appears to him to be or to contain, or to be likely to be or to contain, evidence of an offence under this Part or section 273C; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: seize, remove or detain—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: any article which appears to him to be an infringing copy of a copyright work or an article specifically designed or adapted for making copies of a particular copyright work which appears to him to be intended for use for making infringing copies of any such work;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: anything which appears to him to be or to contain, or to be likely to be or to contain, evidence of an offence under this Part or section 273C; and

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: any vessel, aircraft or vehicle (other than a ship of war or a military aircraft or vehicle) which he reasonably suspects to be or, has been used in connection with an offence under this Part or section 273C. (Amended 16 of 2022 s. 66)

subsection.leadIn: An authorized officer may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: break into and forcibly enter any place which he is empowered or authorized by this Part to enter and search; (Amended 22 of 1998 s. 45)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: forcibly board any vessel, aircraft or vehicle which he is empowered by this Part to stop, board and search;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: remove by force any person or thing obstructing him in the exercise of any power conferred on him by this Part;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: detain any person found in any place which he is empowered or authorized by this Part to search until such place has been searched;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: prevent any person from approaching or boarding any vessel, aircraft or vehicle which he is empowered by this Part to stop, board and search until it has been searched.

subsection.content: An authorized officer may call upon any authorized officer to assist him in the exercise of any of his powers under this section. (Added 22 of 1998 s. 45)

section.name: s123
section.heading: Authority to issue warrant for entry and search

subsection.content: A magistrate may, if he is satisfied by information on oath that there are reasonable grounds for suspecting that there is in any place any article or thing which may be seized, removed or detained under section 122(1)(b), issue a warrant authorizing an authorized officer to enter and search the place.
Subject to subsection (3), an authorized officer shall not enter and search any place under section 122(1)(a)(i) except under the authority of a warrant issued under this section.

An authorized officer may enter and search any place under section 122(1)(a)(i) without a warrant issued under this section if the delay necessary to obtain a warrant could result in the loss or destruction of evidence or for any other reason it would not be reasonably practicable to obtain a warrant.

section.name: s124
section.heading: Obstruction of investigating officers

subsection.leadIn: Without prejudice to any other Ordinance, any person who—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: wilfully obstructs an authorized officer in the exercise of his powers or the performance of his duties under this Ordinance;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: wilfully fails to comply with any requirement properly made to him by any such authorized officer; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: without reasonable excuse, fails to give such authorized officer any other assistance which he may reasonably require to be given for the purpose of exercising his powers or performing his duties under this Ordinance,

subsection.continued: is guilty of an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 4 and to imprisonment for 3 months.

subsection.content: Any person who, when required to give information to an authorized officer in the exercise of his powers or the performance of his duties under this Ordinance, knowingly gives false or misleading information to any such authorized officer is guilty of an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 4 and to imprisonment for 3 months.
Nothing in this section requires any person to give any information which may incriminate him.

section.name: s125
section.heading: Liability of persons other than principal offender

subsection.content: Where a body corporate commits an offence under this Ordinance in respect of any act which is shown to have been committed with the consent or connivance of, or to be attributable to any act on the part of, any director, manager, secretary or other similar officer of the body corporate or any person purporting to act in any such capacity he, as well as the body corporate, commits the offence.

Where the affairs of a body corporate are managed by its members, subsection (1) applies in relation to the acts of a member in connection with his functions of management as if he were a director of the body corporate.

Where an offence under this Ordinance committed by a partner in a partnership is proved to have been committed with the consent or connivance of, or to be attributable to any act on the part of, any other partner of the partnership or any person concerned in the management of the partnership, that other partner or the person concerned in the management of the partnership commits the like offence.

section.name: s126
section.heading: Disclosure of information, etc.

subsection.leadIn: Where any article seized or detained under section 122 is, or is reasonably suspected by the Commissioner to be—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an infringing copy of a copyright work; (Amended 16 of 2022 s. 67)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an article specifically designed or adapted for making copies of a particular copyright work which has been used, or is intended to be used, for the making of infringing copies of any such work; or (Amended 16 of 2022 s. 67)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: if an effective technological measure under section 273C(1) has been applied in relation to a copyright work—a relevant device as defined by section 273C(2), (Added 16 of 2022 s. 67)

subsection.continued: the Commissioner shall, wherever reasonably practicable, notify the owner of the copyright in question or his authorized agent of the seizure or detention, as the case may be.

subsection.leadIn: In the circumstances specified in subsection (1), the Commissioner may disclose to the owner of the copyright or to his authorized agent—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the time, and the address or place, of seizure or detention of the article;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the name and address of the person from whom the article has been seized or detained;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the nature and quantity of articles seized or detained;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: any statement made to the Commissioner or an authorized officer by the person in connection with the seizure or detention, either with the prior consent in writing of that person or without such consent where the person is dead or cannot after reasonable enquiries by the Commissioner as to his whereabouts be found by the Commissioner; and

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: any other information or document relating to the article seized or detained which the Commissioner thinks fit to disclose.

subsection.leadIn: The owner of the copyright or his authorized agent—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: where he seeks disclosure of any information or document that is not referred to in subsection (2); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: where information or a document that is referred to in subsection (2) is not disclosed by the Commissioner,

subsection.continued: may apply to the Court of First Instance for an order requiring the Commissioner to disclose such information or document and the Court of First Instance may on such an application make such order for disclosure as it thinks fit.(Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

subsection.content: An application under subsection (3) may be begun by motion with previous notice to the Commissioner.

section.name: s127
section.heading: Protection of informers in criminal proceedings

subsection.content: Save where, in the opinion of the court, justice so requires, the name or identity of any informer and the information given by such informer shall not be disclosed in any criminal proceedings under this Part.
The court may make any order and adopt any procedure necessary to prevent any such disclosure.

section.name: s128
section.heading: Inspection of articles, release of samples, etc.

subsection.leadIn: Where an article seized or detained under section 122 is, or is reasonably suspected by the Commissioner to be—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an infringing copy of a copyright work; (Amended 16 of 2022 s. 68)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an article specifically designed or adapted for making copies of a particular copyright work which has been used, or is intended to be used, for the making of infringing copies of any such work; or (Amended 16 of 2022 s. 68)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: if an effective technological measure under section 273C(1) has been applied in relation to a copyright work—a relevant device as defined by section 273C(2), (Added 16 of 2022 s. 68)

subsection.continued: the Commissioner or an authorized officer may give the owner of the copyright work in question or his authorized agent or the person from whom the article was seized sufficient opportunity to inspect the article for the purposes of ascertaining whether the article is an infringing copy of the copyright work, or is an article specifically designed or adapted for making infringing copies of the copyright work, or is a relevant device as defined by section 273C(2). (Amended 16 of 2022 s. 68)

subsection.content: Where more than one article is seized or detained under section 122, the Commissioner or an authorized officer may permit the owner of the copyright or his authorized agent or the person from whom the articles were seized or detained to remove samples of the seized or detained articles if the Commissioner or authorized officer considers it necessary for the purpose of ascertaining whether the articles are infringing copies of the copyright work, or are articles specifically designed or adapted for making copies of the copyright work, or are relevant devices as defined by section 273C(2), on condition that the owner or agent or person, as the case may be, gives the Commissioner or authorized officer the requisite undertakings. (Amended 16 of 2022 s. 68)

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (2), the requisite undertakings are undertakings in writing that the person giving the undertaking will—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: return the samples to the Commissioner or authorized officer at a specified time that is satisfactory to the Commissioner or authorized officer; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: take reasonable care to prevent unnecessary damage to the samples.

subsection.leadIn: If the Commissioner or an authorized officer permits the inspection of any seized or detained article, or the removal of a sample, by the copyright owner or his agent or the person from whom the article was seized in accordance with this section, the Government is not liable to the person from whom the article was seized or detained for any loss or damage suffered by him arising out of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: damage to any article incurred during the inspection; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: anything done by the copyright owner or any other person to, or in relation to, a sample removed by the copyright owner, his agent or the person or any use made by the owner or the person of such sample.

section.name: s129
section.heading: Multilateral co-operation
section.leadIn: The Commissioner may, for the purpose of promoting multi-lateral co-operation in the protection of intellectual property rights, disclose information obtained in pursuance of this Ordinance to the customs authorities or other authorities responsible for the enforcement of intellectual property rights of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any country, territory or area which is, at the relevant time, a member of the World Trade Organization; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: such other country, territory or area as the Commissioner thinks fit.

section.name: s130
section.heading: Offences relating to disclosure of information

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (2), any person who discloses to any other person any information obtained by him in pursuance of this Ordinance commits an offence unless the disclosure was made—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for the purpose of the performance by him or any other person of functions under this Ordinance; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: under the direction or order of a court.

subsection.leadIn: A person does not commit an offence under subsection (1) by—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: disclosing information under section 126(1) or (2) or under an order of the Court of First Instance under section 126(3);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: disclosing information under section 129;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: disclosing information under section 140(1) or under an order of the Court of First Instance made under section 140(2); or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: disclosing information under section 267(1) or under an order of the Court of First Instance made under section 267(2). (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

subsection.content: Any person who commits an offence under subsection (1) is liable on conviction to a fine at level 4 and to imprisonment for 1 year.

section.name: s131
section.heading: Seized articles, etc. liable to forfeiture

subsection.content: Any article, vessel, aircraft, vehicle or thing seized or detained by an authorized officer under section 122 is liable to forfeiture in accordance with the following provisions whether or not any person has been charged of an offence under section 118, 119A, 119B, 120 or 273C. (Amended 4 of 2004 s. 4; 15 of 2007 s. 37; 16 of 2022 s. 69)

The Commissioner shall, subject to subsection (3) and not later than 30 days beginning on the date of the seizure or detention of the article, vessel, aircraft, vehicle or thing serve notice of the seizure or detention on a person who was to the knowledge of the Commissioner at the time of, or immediately after seizure or detention, an owner of the article, vessel, aircraft, vehicle or thing.

subsection.leadIn: Subsection (2) does not apply if the article, vessel, aircraft, vehicle or thing was seized or detained in the presence of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an owner, or an employee or agent of the owner, of the article, vessel, aircraft, vehicle or thing;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the person whose offence or suspected offence gave rise to the seizure or detention; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: in the case of a vessel, aircraft or vehicle, the master or person in charge.

subsection.leadIn: A notice given under subsection (2) is deemed to have been duly served if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: it is delivered to the person on whom it is served;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: it is sent by registered post addressed to such person at the place of residence or business of such person, if any, known to the Commissioner; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: where it cannot be served in accordance with paragraph (a) or (b), the notice is exhibited at the Customs and Excise Department, in a place to which the public have access, for a period of not less than 7 days commencing within 30 days from the date of the seizure or detention of the article, vessel, aircraft, vehicle or thing.

subsection.leadIn: If an article, vessel, aircraft, vehicle or thing is liable to forfeiture under subsection (1), the owner or the authorized agent of the owner thereof, or a person who was in possession thereof at the time of seizure or detention, or a person who has a legal or equitable interest in it, may within 30 days beginning—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on the date of the seizure or detention; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: where the notice under subsection (2) is—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: served by delivery to the person to be served, on the date of service; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: sent by registered post, 2 days after the date of posting; or

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: exhibited as described in subsection (4)(c), on the first day it is so exhibited,

subsection.continued: give notice in writing to the Commissioner of his full name and address for service in Hong Kong and claim that the article, vessel, aircraft, vehicle or thing is not liable to forfeiture.

subsection.content: A claimant may withdraw a notice of a claim at any time by notice in writing to the Commissioner.

Except where a person is charged with an offence under section 118, 119A, 119B, 120 or 273C in connection with the seized or detained article, vessel, aircraft, vehicle or thing, if on the date of the expiration of the appropriate period of time specified in subsection (5) for the giving of a notice of claim no such notice has been given in writing to the Commissioner, the article, vessel, aircraft, vehicle or thing is forfeited forthwith to the Government. (Amended 22 of 1999 s. 3; 4 of 2004 s. 4; 15 of 2007 s. 37; 16 of 2022 s. 69)

section.name: s132
section.heading: Disposal of articles, etc. where a person is charged
section.leadIn: Without prejudice to section 131, where a person is charged with an offence under section 118, 119A, 119B, 120 or 273C the court may, if it is satisfied that any article, vessel, aircraft, vehicle or thing seized or detained by an authorized officer under section 122 in connection with the offence— (Amended 4 of 2004 s. 5; 15 of 2007 s. 38; 16 of 2022 s. 70)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is an infringing copy of a copyright work;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: is an article specifically designed or adapted for making copies of a particular copyright work which article has been used, or is intended to be used, for making infringing copies of any such work; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: has been used in connection with any offence under this Ordinance,

section.continued: order that the article, vessel, aircraft, vehicle or thing be—

paragraph.name: i
ii
paragraph.content: delivered up to the person who appears to the court to be the owner of the copyright concerned; or

paragraph.name: iii
paragraph.content: disposed of in such other way as the court may think fit,

section.continued: whether or not the person charged is convicted of the offence with which he was charged.

section.name: s133
section.heading: Determination of application for forfeiture

subsection.content: Where a notice of claim is given under section 131, the Commissioner or an authorized officer shall apply to a magistrate, the District Court or the Court of First Instance for the forfeiture of the article, vessel, aircraft, vehicle or thing unless the Commissioner is satisfied, within a reasonable period after the receipt of the notice of claim, that, on the basis of the evidence of the case, the article, vessel, aircraft, vehicle or thing concerned should be delivered to the claimant. (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)
The Commissioner or authorized officer shall state in the application the name and address of the claimant.

Where an application under subsection (1) is made to a magistrate, the magistrate shall issue a summons to the claimant, requiring him to appear before a magistrate upon the hearing of the application, and shall cause a copy of such summons to be served upon the Commissioner.
Where an application under subsection (1) is made to the District Court or the Court of First Instance, it may be begun by motion. (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

Where the claimant is the defendant in criminal proceedings under section 118, 119A, 119B, 120 or 273C in connection with the seized or detained article, vessel, aircraft, vehicle or thing and there is no other claimant, on an application made in that behalf by the Commissioner, the court may hear the forfeiture application immediately following the criminal proceedings and for the purposes of a hearing under this subsection, any requirement in respect of the issue or service of a summons or any notice of the hearing under or by virtue of subsection (3) or (4), as the case may be, does not apply. (Amended 4 of 2004 s. 6; 15 of 2007 s. 39; 16 of 2022 s. 71)
